A star (*) denotes that prisoners have been previously in custodyâ€”two stars (**) that they have been more than once in custodyâ€”a dagger (â€ ) that they are known to be the associates of bad charactersâ€”the figures after the name in the indictment denote the prisoner's age.
LONDON AND MIDDLESEX CASES.

198.
ROBERT HENRY CUMMING otherwise
HUGH MORDUANT (26)
PLEADED GUILTY to
stealing a trunk and other articles, the property of
Hanway Cumming, having been convicted at this Court on November 18th, 1901, as Hugh Morduant.
Twelve months' hard labour. â€”

(199)
THOMAS WRIGHT (38)
, to robbery on
Frederick Merchant, and stealing a watch and chain, having been convicted of being found by night with house-breaking implements in his possession on November 20th, 1900. Four other convictions were proved against him.
Five years' penal servitude. â€”
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

(200)
HENRY HERBERT HUTCHINGS (30)
. to stealing, whilst employed under the Post Office, two post letters containing three postal orders for 10s. each, one for 7s. 6d., and one for 4s., the property of the
Postmaster-General.
Nine months in the second division. â€”

(201)

, to robbery on

Three years' penal servitude. â€”
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.] And

(202)
THOMAS BIGNALL (34)
, to receiving a ring and a necklet, the property of
Charles Farley, well knowing them to have been stolen.
Three years' penal servitude.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

203.
EUGENE BELLANGER (28) and
LOUIS FREDERICK BODIER (32)
. Robbery with violence on
Martha Mercier, and stealing from her person a purse, two notes on the Bank of France for 100 francs each, and 5s. 6d., her money.
MR. HARDY Prosecuted, MR. JENKINS Defended Bodier; and the evidence was interpreted.
MARTHA MERCIER . I am an embroiderer, of 54, Huntley Streetâ€”on

January 8th I was in Tottenham Street about 5 p.m.â€”I went into Peltier's French circulating library to change some moneyâ€”I do not know if anyone came into the shop while I was thereâ€”when I went into Tottenham Street again, Bellanger came up and took my purseâ€”he ran away and I pursued himâ€”at the corner of the street I was pushed, I think by Bodier but I am not sureâ€”when we got to Charles Street, Bodier saw that I was overtaking Bellanger and he tripped me upâ€”I fell, and when I got up a policeman was holding Bellangerâ€”Bodier said that the thief had been arrested, and I then recognised him as the man who had tripped meâ€”he was then arrestedâ€”I lost sight of him for about three minutes after he tripped meâ€”when I saw him again we were in Charlotte Placeâ€”I went to the station with themâ€”at the station Bellanger said that if I got him locked up my money would be lost, and "If you set me free I will return you the money"â€”he told me the purse was in good handsâ€”I did not hear what the prisoners said in answer to the chargeâ€”there was a detective there who could speak French.
Cross-examined by Bellanger. You squeezed my hand to take the money from it.

Cross-examined by MR. JENKINS. I do not know if Bodier was in the shop when I was thereâ€”I will not swear that he is the man who pushed me or tripped meâ€”when Bellanger ran away I called out "Au voleur," which means "stop thief"â€”I did not see Bodier running after Bellanger after I had called' out an voleurâ€”when I was running after Bellanger a few people were running, but not many.
Re-examined. I had 350 francs in my purse in French bank-notes, 20 francs in gold, and 5s. 6d. and a few coppers in English money.

CORNELIUS SEXTON (Police Inspector.) On January 8th, about 5.45 p.m I was in Charlotte Street with Sergeant McIntyre in plain clothesâ€”I heard cries of "Stop thief" in French, which I knowâ€”I saw Bellanger running in the direction of Percy Streetâ€”I ran after him across Gooch Street, where I fell beneath a cabâ€”I got up and followed him into Charlotte Passage, where he was knocked down by a constable; he said, "Jen'airien" which means "I have got nothing." Bodier then rushed up followed by the prosecutrixâ€”she said in French three times, "C'est lui" which is "That is he"â€”in the prisoner's hearing a French boy who was there said that it was the small prisoner (Bellanger) who stole the prosecutrix's purse, and that the other had knocked her downâ€”the prisoners made no answer, and I directed the constable to take Bellanger to the station, while I took Bodierâ€”I only remained a short time at the station.

Cross-examined by MR. JENKINS. The French boy gave evidence at the police courtâ€”he is not here, he was got out of the country by the prisoner's associatesâ€”this quarter of London is a French oneâ€”I was about 15 or 17 yards from the prosecutrix when I heard the cry of "Stop thief"â€”I did not see Bodier until I got up to Bellangerâ€”Bodier was running behind Bellangerâ€”Bodier came up, although he had seen Bellanger collared by the constableâ€”it was a narrow passageâ€”not more than six people were running after Bellanger when I began to run, but there must have been about twenty there when I was talking to himâ€”there were
some French people among themâ€”the boy was the only one who was speaking French.
Cross-examined by Bellanger. Both of you were very violent at the station.

PETER MCINTYRE (Police Sergeant.) I was with Sexton on January 8th in Charlotte Street about 3.45â€”I heard a cry of "Auvoleur"â€”I saw several people running, Bellanger was one of themâ€”I saw him stopped by a constableâ€”Bodier then came up, followed by the prosecutrix, who was covered with bloodâ€”I said to her in French, "We are police officers, do not be afraid, what is the matter"â€”she said, "The big one," pointing to Bodier, "took my purse and the little one knocked me down"â€”they were taken to the station and Bellanger said to the prosecutrix, "The money is in good hands, don't have me arrested and I will see if I can get it back for you"â€”they were chargedâ€”Bellanger said, "I heard a cry of 'Au voleur'; I followed the man and fell in the mud as you see, then the policeman arrested me"â€”Bodier said, "I heard a cry of 'Au voleur,' I followed the man, when I came up the policeman arrested me.
Cross-examined by MR. JENKINS. Although Bodier saw Bellanger arrested he came up to the same spot.

By the COURT. The French boy said in the prisoner's presence, "Je l' ai vu"â€”I said, "What have you seen"â€”he said, "I have seen the little one take the purse and the woman knocked in the road "'â€”I took him to the station and he appeared next day at the police court and gave his evidenceâ€”he is now in Brussels.
By MR. JENKINS. Thirty or forty people were present when I was talking to the prisoner in the roadâ€”only the boy was talking Frenchâ€”Bodier may not have heard what he said.

DAVID MAY (268 D.) I was near Charlotte Street on January 8thâ€”I heard a cryâ€”I do not speak Frenchâ€”I saw the two prisoners running into Charlotte Place and towards meâ€”Bellanger was about 12 yards in front of Bodierâ€”nobody else was running in sight thenâ€”I ran out of the doorway where I was hiding and threw Bellanger to the groundâ€”Bodier was close by thenâ€”he did not attempt to arrest Bellangerâ€”they were taken to the police stationâ€”I heard them charged, they said something in French in answer to it.

Cross-examined by MR. JENKINS. When I had thrown Bellanger to the ground I left him for a minute and went for Bodier, who was trying to run past meâ€”I had them both in custody when the other officers came up.

JOHN MONK (Police-Inspector.) I saw the prisoners at the stationâ€”Bellanger gave his address as 5, South Crescent, and Bodier at 33, Fitzroy Streetâ€”Bodier was not known thereâ€”I went to Bellangers address and searched his boxâ€”I found a six-chambered revolver in it and two letters.

Cross-examined by MR. JENKINS. I went to Bodier's address at 35, Fitzroy Squareâ€”I saw a Mrs. Kingston there, who said that Bodier did not live thereâ€”I went in and insisted that he didâ€”she insisted that he did not.

p.hi: Bellanger, in his defence on oath, said that he saw the lady holding a
purse in her hand; that he lost his head and was tempted to take the purse and ran away with it; and that he was quite alone.

Bodier, in his defence on oath, said that he saw the woman running and crying, "Stop thief"; that several people were running; and he ran behind them till they got up to a policeman, and then he was arrested; and that he did not know Bellanger.

div1.p: MARTHA MERCIER (Re-examined.) I said at the police court that Bodier is the man who pushed me down, and I still think he is the man.

GUILTY . Eight previous convictions were proved against Bellanger and eleven against Bodier, both in Paris.
Seven years' penal servitude each.

204.
WILLIAM PARKER OWEN (36)
PLEADED GUILTY to
forging and uttering two share transfers in the capital stock of the
Indian Glenrock Wynaad Company, Limited, with intent to defraud ;
also to six other indictments for embezzling Â£3,000 the moneys of the said company;
also to two other indictments for embezzling Â£650 the moneys of the
Premier Sunrise New Zealand Gold Mining Company, Limited, his masters.
He re
ceived a good character.
Eighteen months' hard labourâ€”And

(205).
THOMAS ADAMS (32)
. to carnally knowing
Emily Gad bold, a girl between the ages of thirteen and sixteen.
Three months' hard labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

206.
WILLIAM JOHNSON (59)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

ANNIE MILLER . I am the wife of Herbert Miller, a newsagent and tobacconist of Union Street, Maryleboneâ€”on January 7th, about 7 p.m., a woman came in with a soldier and bought some cigarettes, price 1d.â€”she gave me a shilling, which I broke; she then gave me a florin; I did not like the look of it and gave it back to her, and she gave me a pennyâ€”she took the two broken pieces of the shilling with herâ€”I spoke to my husband.

HERBERT MILLER . I am the husband of the last witnessâ€”she spoke to me on January 7th when I was outside the shop, and pointed out a woman, who went down Mortimer Street and met the prisoner and gave him some moneyâ€”she met a soldier and they all went on together; the woman went into a baker's shop, 65, Cleveland Streetâ€”I waited outside and when she came out I went in, and a shilling was tested in my presence and found to be badâ€”I went out and followed the woman, and saw her pass more moneyâ€”they all went to Great Portland Street and into a public-houseâ€”when the woman came out I went in, and afterwards followed her and saw her pass something to the prisonerâ€”I then saw a policeman, and he arrested the prisonerâ€”the woman walked off and threw something down an area grating of a barber's shopâ€”I pointed out the place to Smith the constableâ€”I followed the woman to London Road and lost sight of herâ€”I am sure the prisoner is the same man, I kept him under observation three-quarters of an hour.
MARGARET TIERNAN . I live at 65, Cleveland Street, and assist Mr.

Newerdorf, a bakerâ€”on January 7th, about 7 p.m., a woman came in for penny cake and gave me 1s.: I gave her 11d. change, and put it in the tillâ€”when she left, Miller came in and said something; I went to the till took out the same coin and bent itâ€”these are the pieces (Produced.)

ALFRED TAYLOR (295 D.) On January 7th. about 7.45, Mr. Miller spoke to me, and I saw the prisoner and a soldier and a tall, dark womanâ€”I had seen them in company beforeâ€”I followed them to Portland Road and arrested the prisonerâ€”I told him it was on suspicion of being concerned with two others in passing bad moneyâ€”he said he knew nothing about itâ€”I searched him at once, and found 17s. in silver and 1s. 7 1/2 d. in bronze: there was one half-crown, also two packets of matches, two packets of tea, marked 2d. unopened, and about an ounce of tobacco, part of which was in a boxâ€”I asked him where he livedâ€”he said, "I refuse to tell you"â€”he was charged before the inspector, but made no answer.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I have not said that you were walking with the woman when I arrested youâ€”there was not another constable on the other side of the road who I could have calledâ€”the woman was thirty yards from me.
JOHN SMITH (Policeman D.) Miller pointed out an area to me at 248, Great Portland Street; I went down and found this shilling (Produced).
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . I am inspector of coin to H.M. Mintâ€”this shilling is bad, and these two pieces of a shilling also, and they are from the same mould.
The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate. "I know nothing about the woman or the soldier."

Prisoner's defence. There was no woman and no soldier. I was never in Cleveland Street or Union Street. They brought forward this shilling, but they allowed the woman to walk away. I never spoke to any woman. I had nothing but good money on me.

GUILTY .
Nine months' hard labour.

207.
FREDERICK WILSON (27),
PLEADED GUILTY to
three indictments for forging and uttering orders for the delivery of grocery with intent to defraud, and to a conviction at Clerkenwell on December 4th, 1900.
Four other convictions were proved against him.
Fifteen months' hard labour. â€”

(208)
WILLIAM BARRETT (65)
, to three indictments for fraudulently adding the figures 16s. to three cheques with intent to defraud;
also to unlawfully making a false entry in a wages book of his employers.
Twelve months' hard labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

209.
WILLIAM BUTCHER (40)
, Stealing a mare and a set of harness, the property of
Charles Dix. Second count Receiving the same.
MR. ROOTH Prosecuted and Mr. Burney Defended.

CHARLES DIX . I am a fishmonger of 19, College Street, Putneyâ€”on December 27th I drove with a man named Lansdell to Smithfield Marketâ€”I drove a bay mare in a costermonger's barrowâ€”the harness was brass mountedâ€”I left it with Wilson, who minds carts outside the market, at 12 in the dayâ€”we were in the market an hour and a halfâ€”I then sent Lans
dell

out; he came back and told me something and I went out and could not find the barrowâ€”I identified the mare and harness at the station a few days after Christmas, and the barrow at Shepherd's Walkâ€”they are worth Â£45 or Â£30.

JOHN WILSON . I am a cart minderâ€”on December 27th Dicks left a pony and barrow with meâ€”he was with Mr. Lansdellâ€”somebody, not the prisoner, came and spoke to me and took the barrow and horse awayâ€”I have not seen the man since.

CHARLES LANSDELL . I am a fishmonger of 127. Park Road, Wandsworthâ€”I accompanied Mr. Dix to Smithfield Market on December 27thâ€”he left a horse and barrow outside with Wilsonâ€”when I went out to look for them they were goneâ€”I was driving in York Road. Battersea, on Saturday, at 9.30 and saw the prisoner driving Mr. Dix's pony in a truckâ€”another man was with him and another horse was tied behind with a halterâ€”I spoke to an officer who stopped the prisoner and took him in custodyâ€”there was a sack in the cart containing harness, and another sack containing these irons (Jemmies)â€”I did not see what became of the other man.

WILLIAM ROBERTS (731 W.) On January 3rd, about 9.15, Lansdell spoke to me, and in consequence of what he said I stopped the prisoner who was driving a bay mare with harness on, in a cartâ€”another man was in the cart, and a horse was tied to the toil of the cartâ€”I told the prisoner I should take him into custody for being in unlawful possession of the horse and cartâ€”lie said, "All right, I will come with you"â€”on the way to the station he said, "I bought it"â€”the other man went away.

Cross-examined. The prosecutor identified the mare which was in the cartâ€”a witness was called for the defence in reference to the gelding behindâ€”when the prisoner said, "I will go with you," the other man slipped down behind and ran away.

CHARLES GOGGINS (Detective Officer W.) I was in Clapham Police Station on January 13th when the prisoner was brought inâ€”there was a black wooden cart there, newly painted, bearing no name, and a brown mare in the shafts, and in the cart some black leather harness, brass mounted, and a sack containing these two jemmiesâ€”I asked the prisoner how he accounted for having the things in his possession; he said, "I do not know who it belongs to; a man asked me to put it in my cart as his cart was broken down. I have not seen him before or since, neither do I know who he is"â€”I said, "Have you any stables?"â€”he said, "I decline to tell you where my stables are, as I do not wish to bring anyone else into it"â€”he said to the Sergeant, "I was at Wimbledon at six o'clock this morning selling grapes. I cannot tell you anybody's name who I sold them to"â€”he was placed in the cells and I searched him and found a cab file on him.

Cross-examined. He has told the police since from whom he bought the cartâ€”there was no charge in reference to the cart or the geldingâ€”I thoroughly examined the cart but found no trace of grapesâ€”the harness was on the pony.

FRANK HALLAM (City Detective Sergeant.) On January 3rd, about 1.30 p.m., I went with Beckley to Clapham Police Station and saw the prisoner detained thereâ€”I said, "I have seen a horse and harness which were

stolen on December 22nd, and were found in your possession"â€”he said, "I bought the horse and harness yesterday outside the White Horse public-house, Caledonian Market. I gave Â£14 for the Jot I don't know the man from whom I bought it: I had never seen him before. This morning I went out and sold them at Wimbledon, and as I was coming back I gave the other man a lift as his cart was broken down and he tied his horse to the back of my cart and put his harness in; I do not know the man, I have never seen him before. I do not know where it was that the cart broke down"â€”I asked him the address of his stables; he said, "I refuse to say, the cart I was driving is my property, I have had it some years."
Cross-examined. I am not quite satisfied that the cart was his ownâ€”a witness came to identify it, but some additions had been made to itâ€”that witness was subpÅ“naed by the police.

JAMES HEALEY (3 G.) On January 5th I saw a barrow standing un
attended in Gordon Street, Islingtonâ€”it contained a sack and some brass-mounted pony harnessâ€”I took it to the station, and Dix identified it.

GEORGE SAMUEL JACKSON . I am a fishmonger of 100, Hart Street, Bethnal Greenâ€”on January 5th I received a telegram, went to the City Road Police Station, and saw a barrow which I had sold him, and which he identified.

GUILTY on the second count.
He then
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction at Hereford on October 16th, 1890. Three other convictions were proved against him, and the police stated that he was connected with a gang of horse stealers.
Five years' penal servitude.

210.
WILLIAM ELLINGTON (49)
was charged on the Coroner's Inquisition only, with the manslaughter of
Elizabeth Ellington.
The Grand Jury having thrown out the Bill, Mr. MUIR, for the Prosecution, offered no evidence on the Inquisition.
NOT GUILTY .

211.
WILLIAM ELLINGTON was again indicted
for, that he, having the care and custody of
Francis William Ellington, did neglect him in a manner likely to cause him unnecessary suffering and injury to his health.

JOHN ELLINGTON . I am sixteen years old, and am the prisoner's eldest sonâ€”I now live at 23, Compton Street, Tottenhamâ€”up to my mother's death, on January 17th, I lived with my parents at 2, Princes Street, Tottenhamâ€”I have been at work for about four yearsâ€”we occupied a front and back room at Princes Streetâ€”I slept in the front room with my brothers Thomas and Joseph, the latter is six years old, I think; also with my sisters Rose and Emilyâ€”Rose was the youngest childâ€”there was a large bed and a small cot in the roomâ€”I slept in the cot, and the other children in the bedâ€”my father and mother occupied the back roomâ€”about Christmas time I noticed my mother was very dirty and sat by the side of the fire and would do nothingâ€”she got worse and would sit on the side of

the bed and try to walk into the back roomâ€”she could not walk without assistanceâ€”the last time she could not walk without assistance was about a week after Christmasâ€”she was able to walk about again with assistance as she got a bit betterâ€”the room where we slept was very dirtyâ€”while my mother was ill nobody came in to clean the room or the children.

Cross-examined. My father is a hard-working manâ€”he went out to work every morningâ€”the day before my mother died my father got her some tea and breakfast before he went to workâ€”he was away at work from 6 a.m. till 8 or 9 p.m. every dayâ€”we always had plenty to eat and drink in the houseâ€”my father bought clothes for the childrenâ€”I do not know if he had any difficulty in getting the house cleaned just before my mother diedâ€”I remember his complaining to her about the state of the roomâ€”she said she was not going to do any more work, she had done her shareâ€”while she was ill my father used to fetch things for her and nurse her while he was at home.
SARAH HILL . The prisoner married my sister, who died on January 17thâ€”I went to the house that dayâ€”I looked into the front roomâ€”the bedstead and room was very dirtyâ€”I did not see any bedding.
Cross-examined. I do not remember if the prisoner once asked if he should fetch a doctor.

EMILY SAMME . I am the wife of William Sammeâ€”the prisoner is my brotherâ€”his son John will be sixteen next May; Francis William was fourteen last October; Joseph nine last October I think; Emily will be thirteen next November, and Rosie six next March.

WILLIAM JAMES ANDREWS . I am an officer in the S.P.C.C.â€”on January 17th I received a communication from Dr. Rostante, and at 9 p.m. I went to 2, Princes Street, Tottenhamâ€”I saw the prisoner in the back kitchen on the ground floorâ€”he was drunkâ€”I saw his youngest daughter Rose, who was in a very dirty conditionâ€”she had only an old skirt on, but I saw some other clothing which had been brought there by Mrs. Sammeâ€”in the back room on the first floor I saw Francis William Ellington, aged fourteen, and Josephâ€”they were both filthily dirty, and nearly blackâ€”Francis William had scabs all over his scalp, and he was wearing only an adult's overcoatâ€”Joseph was wearing an old waistcoat and a pair of knickersâ€”I saw in the room a small piece of bread and a few raw potatoesâ€”the room was filthily dirtyâ€”in the front room the mattresses were filthily dirty, and in the centre of the room there was a palliasse filthily dirty and rottenâ€”in a corner of the room I saw a cot on which were two mattresses filthily dirtyâ€”they were rotten and there was coal dust and other things between themâ€”all over the room there were numerous pieces of rags and old garmentsâ€”the room presented the appearance of not having been cleaned or swept for a long timeâ€”next morning I went again with Dr. Rostante and saw the three children again and also Emilyâ€”she was fairly clean and in fairly good conditionâ€”I called the prisoner's attention to the condition of the children and his homeâ€”he said, "I earn on an average 36s. a week; my son Frederick earned about 8s. last week and the week before that he only worked about four days; I used to sub on my friends; I gave my wife
about 1s. 6d. a day, and on Saturdays I gave her 14s., whilst I paid the rent, 4s. 6d."

Cross-examined. Emily is twelve years oldâ€”Francis William is fourteenâ€”he is not very intelligentâ€”he does not go to workâ€”he seems rather dullâ€”he has not been to school for a long time I believeâ€”Joseph is eight years oldâ€”I believe he goes to schoolâ€”I do not know that any complaints have been made by the school about his conditionâ€”the prisoner was perfectly sober on the day after his wife's death.

ANDREW ROSTANTE . I am a registered medical practitioner, and practice at Tottenhamâ€”I was called in to see the prisoner's wife on January 17thâ€”I saw two very dirty-looking and badly-clad childrenâ€”I do not know their namesâ€”one was about fourteenâ€”I did not examine themâ€”I told the Society's officer of the state of the children, and especially the room, which was extremely dirty and offensive in smellâ€”on the 18th I examined the childrenâ€”Francis William, who did not appear to be fourteen, was in an extremely filthy conditionâ€”his head was covered with lice and a disease we call impetigo, which is brought on by liceâ€”John and Emily were fairly clean, but Rose was in practically the same condition as Francis Williamâ€”I should say that the state of their heads was caused by lice, vermin, and the filthy state of their bed, which was covered with excrement: that would be likely to cause unnecessary suffering and injury to their healthâ€”I made a post mortem on their motherâ€”I do not think she was fit to do any house-hold duties for three months before her death.

Cross-examined. The uncleanliness of the children was not due to the syphilitic ulcers which their mother was suffering fromâ€”their condition had nothing to do with syphilisâ€”syphilis affects the skinâ€”these children would not be more likely to suffer from impetigo than children coming from a healthy motherâ€”it is very common in dirty childrenâ€”they were in a worse condition than those we generally seeâ€”I have not examined the prisonerâ€”Francis William's head had been recently washedâ€”I do not know if that was done by the prisonerâ€”I saw Rose at a relative's house.

JOHN MILLER . I am foreman to Messrs. Bright and Co., lamp manu
facturers, of 37. Brutton Streetâ€”the prisoner has been employed there for the last thirty-five yearsâ€”he earns 31s. a week, and full time 35s.â€”he is an industrious man.
Cross-examined. We have no complaint to make of him.
NOT GUILTY .

212.
GEORGE OLIVER (23)
, Feloniously attempting to discharge a loaded pistol at
George Harrold, with intent to murder him. Second Count, with intent to do him grievous bodily harm.

GEORGE HARROLD . I am master of the City of London Union Casual Wardâ€”I reside thereâ€”on January 22nd, the prisoner applied to be ad
mittedâ€”applications have to be made to me for accommodation, of which there are two sorts, dormatories and cellsâ€”the men sleep alone in the cellsâ€”I gave the prisoner a ticket for a cell, which he refusedâ€”I said, "If you refuse to accept the accommodation I offer you, there is only one thing for

you to do, that is for you to go out again," and I called the porter to let him outâ€”the porter was not in the lodge, and I went to call himâ€”I went back into the lodge with himâ€”the porter went by the prisoner to open the door, and I saw the prisoner holding something towards me, but there is a shade to my lamp, and I could not distinguish what it wasâ€”the porter said, "Look out, master, he has got a revolver"â€”he crossed to the prisoner, there was a struggleâ€”I called for assistance, and went out to fetch the policeâ€”when the porter caught hold of him he said, "Oh, I don't mean it for you, it is meant for that b----over there,"' meaning meâ€”I was the only other officer there at the time.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I can swear that you pointed the revolver at me.
By the COURT. I do not know where he had his finger.
By the JURY. When I offered him the cell ticket, he said, "I got fourteen days a little while ago through you giving me a cell ticket"â€”he had refused to do his work, and broke a window.
Re-examined. I charged him for that, and he got the fourteen days.

LEONARD SANGUIN . I am porter at the City of London Ward, Shoe Laneâ€”on January 22nd. the prisoner applied for admissionâ€”I admitted him and told him to apply at the master's officeâ€”I then went out of the lodgeâ€”I was fetched back by the master, in order to put the prisoner outâ€”I went into the lodge with the master and then went to open the doorâ€”I turned round and then shouted out, "Look out, master, he has got a revolver"â€”the prisoner was standing with a revolver in his left handâ€”I made a rush at him, and grasped his arm, he had his finger on the triggerâ€”I twisted him round, and put him into the corner, holding his arm and the revolverâ€”he said he was sorry it did not go off, and that he did not mean it for me as I was a gentlemanâ€”I was 2 or 2 1/2 yards away from him when I saw his arm go up.
Cross-examined. You were not standing at my back when I turned round, you were standing by my side.

WILLIAM HENRY HANCHETT (334 City.) On January 22nd, I was on duty in Fetter Laneâ€”about 5.30 p.m., the prosecutor called meâ€”I went into the casual ward where I saw the prisoner being held by the porter and the stokerâ€”I saw this revolver given to another constableâ€”the prisoner said to the prosecutor, "It is a lucky thing for you it did not go off"â€”on the way to the station he said, "I had this in store for him"â€”I saw the revolver examined, it was loaded with cartridges, this box of 43 cart
ridges was found on the prisoner, and six were in the revolver.

SAMUEL HOCKLEY (241 City.) On January 22nd. I was called with Hanchettâ€”I took the revolver, but I do not know who fromâ€”there was no struggleâ€”I searched the prisoner, there was a box of cartridges, a tobacco pouch, and a pocket book on him, but no money.

WILLIAM OLIVER . I am a labourer out of work, and with no fixed addressâ€”on January 22nd, I applied for admittance to the City of London Union as a casualâ€”I was admitted about 5.10 p.m.â€”I saw the prisoner about 5.20, and also the masterâ€”I saw the prisoner go towards the master's office, the master asked him a question which I could not hear,

and almost immediately the master handed him a ticketâ€”the prisoner said, "I don't want this b----ticket, it is a cell, I got fourteen days before this, which you know"â€”the master went away for a minuteâ€”I said to my mate, "He has got a shooter"â€”the prisoner put it up to the master's face, he then pulled it down and fumbled with it; before he had time to properly raise it again the porter rushed in and caught him by his right handâ€”the prisoner said, "Be careful, you will have it go off, I did not want to shoot you, you are a gentleman"â€”then the police came in, and the revolver was seized away from the prisonerâ€”I cannot swear if he had his finger on the trigger or not.

WALTER BENNETT . I am a painter's labourer. I saw the revolver in the prisoner's hand, and pointing towards the master's faceâ€”I cannot say if his finger was on the trigger or notâ€”I saw him taken away by the policeâ€”he said to the master, "I meant doing for you, whatever I got done to"

FREDERICK THOMAS BARTLETT . I am salesman to Mrs. Dooley, 161, Whitechapel Road; on January 22nd, about mid day I sold this revolver to the prisonerâ€”it has got our stock mark upon it, it was clean then, but slightly faulty; when you got the barrel half round you could not pull the trigger back, but if you got it right under the firing point it was all rightâ€”ot like this when I sold it, it has been tampered with sinceâ€”when it is shot off it won't go off again unless you put the spring back again.

ALFRED WILLIAM BROWN . I am salesman to Arthur Brown, general dealer of 132, Whitechapel Roadâ€”on January 22nd, a man came in to buy some cartridgesâ€”I rather fancy it was the prisoner, but I cannot swear to it.

p.hi: The prisoner, in his defence on oath, said that while he was being held in the corner he took the revolver out of his pocket, but that he had not pointed it at anybody, and had not got it in his hand till then.

div1.p:
213.
FERDINAND CZILINSKY the elder (67)
, Feloniously wounding
George Hyde with intent to murder him. Other Counts with intent to do him grevious bodily harm, to disable him, or to resist his lawful apprehension.

GEORGE HYDE (373 Y.) On December 31st, I received from Constable Lambert four warrants for the prisoner's arrest for the non-payment of ratesâ€”I had had them in October and November, and the early part of Decemberâ€”I tried to execute themâ€”I kept observation on the houseâ€”when anybody went there the door was not opened, but everything was handed in through a little pigeon-holeâ€”on December 31st, I went to his house in Tiverton Road, with Constables White, Lambert, and Pooleâ€”Lambert was in uniform, the rest of us were in plain clothesâ€”I remained' on the door step, and about 7.15 some one opened the trap door, looked out, and said, "It is all right," the bolt was drawn, the catch was pulled back, and the prisoner's son opened the doorâ€”I entered the passage and said, "I am a police officer"â€”the prisoner was upstairs, but his son said, "Out you go," and struck me a heavy blow in the face and I fell downâ€”I then went upstairs followed by Lambert, who had got a lanternâ€”when we got to the front room on the first floor, I knocked at the

door; the prisoner shouted, "Who is there?"â€”I said, "Police officers I have four warrants for your arrest for non-payment of rates"â€”he said, "All right, come in"â€”I pushed the door, but it would only open about six inchesâ€”the room was in total darknessâ€”as soon as the door was opened the prisoner thrust this rapier (Produced) through the doorâ€”it penetrated my coat in two places, but did not wound meâ€”I called out, "You had better be quiet and come out"â€”he said, "All right, come in"â€”he again thrust the sword at me, cutting my thumbâ€”it is very sharpâ€”I again asked him to be quiet, and he again said, "Come in"â€”I thrust the door open and went in, the prisoner was in the cornerâ€”I told him I should arrest himâ€”he said, "If you had not been so quick I should have shot you instead of stabbing you"â€”he had made three or four thrusts through the door before I was able to catch hold of the sword, which I did with my left hand, it was my right hand that was cutâ€”other officers assisted me in taking him to the stationâ€”he was very violent, and had to be nearly arrived.

Cross-examined. I did not burst the front door open, I walked in; the prisoner's sons opened the door themselves, and then they tried to put me outâ€”when I was knocked down they tried to drag me into the streetâ€”g in the passage fell down, but I cannot say what it was, the place was in darknessâ€”two heavy planks did not knock me downâ€”I did not see the rapier upstairs till it went through my coatâ€”I do not know if the prisoner is one of the most expert ebony carvers in London, or if this rapier was sent to him to have a new handle fittedâ€”I think he kept it ready to receive usâ€”I was very roughly handled downstairsâ€”I was examined at the prisoner's requestâ€”I did not knock him about upstairsâ€”I do not know if he is unpopular at Tufnell Parkâ€”I had never seen him beforeâ€”I have heard he is not very popularâ€”he walked to the station quietly, but we had to carry him downstairsâ€”on the way to the station I did not say to him, "You took a rise out of us the other day, but we have got the best of you to-day"â€”I did not hear that remark made to him by one of the other policemenâ€”I did not tell the prisoner I would let him go if he paid his ratesâ€”he would have been taken to the station if he had paid themâ€”no sharp tools fell on my hand and cut it.
Re-examined. The wound was caused by the point of the sword.

JAMES LAMBERT (24 Y. R.) On December 31st I was with Hyde when he went to execute the warrant for the prisoner's arrestâ€”I was in uniformâ€”I saw Hyde go into the house, and then I heard a scuffleâ€”I went in and found Hyde lying on the floor in the passageâ€”he and I went upstairs and knocked at a doorâ€”the prisoner called out, "Who is there?"â€”Hyde replied, "Police officers. I have four warrants for your arrest for non
payment of rates"â€”the prisoner said, "Come in"â€”the door was opened a little bit, and the prisoner thrust a long sword through the opening two or three timesâ€”the door was forced open, and the prisoner said, "I could not see you for the light of your lamp; if you had not been so quick I would have shot you"â€”he was arrested and taken downstairsâ€”Hyde took the sword away from him.
Cross-examined. I gave the warrants to Hydeâ€”we went to the house

prepared for a frayâ€”the other policemen were close byâ€”I did not see Hyde put his foot into the doorway and push the door openâ€”I did not hear him call out "Come on, I am in"â€”I was only three yards awayâ€”White went in before I didâ€”sufficient noise was made downstairs for anyone on the first floor to hearâ€”I heard Hyde say he was a police officerâ€”when we went upstairs the lantern was turned on to the opening of the door, so that Hyde could have seen anything that came outâ€”I did not notice a rack upstairs with some tools in itâ€”some violence took place when we arrested the prisonerâ€”he was not knocked aboutâ€”we required assistance to arrest him, as Hyde was injuredâ€”this room was the prisoner's workshopâ€”I saw some tools thereâ€”I saw Hyde take hold of the sword with his left handâ€”it did not cut his hand, because he caught hold of the hilt.

JONATHAN THOMAS (Inspector Y.) I was at Upper Holloway police station on December 31st when the prisoner was brought inâ€”I examined Hyde's clothingâ€”the prisoner said, "Yes, I stabbed him, I could not get my revolver, he was too quick; I would shoot any policeman or Borough Councilman, it is the only way I can air my grievances; I will say the same before a Magistrate."

PATRICK WHITE RATTRAY . I am Divisional Surgeon at Upper Holloway police stationâ€”on December 31st I examined Hydeâ€”he had a cut on the back of his right thumb; it could have been caused by the point of this rapierâ€”very considerable force would be required to pierce the constable's clothing.

Cross-examined. The cut on his thumb was in the form of a slashâ€”the point of this rapier is capable of making a slash, if it was thrust forwardsâ€”the breadth of the point is infinitesimalâ€”I do not know how a point like this can make a slash, but it can do itâ€”it is not more probable that the wound was caused by the falling of a sharp chisel, but it is possible.

JAMES JOHN CHISNELL . I am a rate collector for the Borough Council of Islingtonâ€”these four warrants were issued and signed by a Magistrateâ€”they are dated February 15th, 1902, February 3rd, August 5th, and November 4thâ€”they were for the non-payment of the ordinary house ratesâ€”I have known the prisoner for many yearsâ€”I have had many disputes with him with regard to rates.

Cross-examined. The prisoner's son said that his father could not get justice, and he brought out a pistol and said he would shoot someone and then see if he could get justiceâ€”rates can be collected without going before a County Court.

p.hi: The prisoner, in his defence on oath, said that he had just put out his gas when he heard some wood which was in his passage fall; that he did not know the police were in the house, because in France, which was his own country, when the police came to the door they had to say, "In the name of the Republic open the door," and he thought it was the same here; that when he heard the noise he was frightened, and tried to barricade the door, but had not time, so took the rapier from his rack, so that anybody who came in could see it and not maltreat him; that Hyde pushed him into the corner, and he got his head cut by a baton: that Hyde must have fallen on the tools
on the bench and cut his thumb; that he did not intend to kill anybody; and that he did not resist his arrest.

div1.p:
HENRY ROXON . I am a shop-fitter, of 17, Victoria Road, Hollowayâ€”on December 31st I was engaged by the prisoner to do some work for him at his houseâ€”I was going to leave the house about 7 p.m.â€”it was dark, and there was no light in the passageâ€”when the constable came in some match-boarding and some pear wood, which was standing in the passage, fellâ€”I was not present when the prisoner came downstairs with the con
stable, as I had been pushed into the kitchen with the prisoner's sonsâ€”the prisoner did not say in the kitchen that he would have shot them allâ€”on the way to the station one of the policemen said, "You have had a good many larks with us, now we have a lark with you on New Year's Eve, how do you like it?"â€”I did not see the prisoner use any violence towards the police.

214.
FERDINAND CZILINSKY. the elder , was again indicted with
FERDINAND CZILINSKY, the younger , and
EMILE LORENZ CZI
LINSKY
with unlawfully assaulting
George Hyde, a police officer, in the execution of his duty.

p.hi: for the Prosecution offered no evidence against Ferdinand Czilinsky the elder.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

GEORGE HYDE . About 7.15 p.m. on December 31st I went with three other officers to 6, Tiverton Road, with some warrants for the arrest of the prisoners' fatherâ€”I stood on the door-stepâ€”I was in plain clothesâ€”a little wicket in the panel of the door was opened by Emile, and someone said, "It is all right, no one is about"â€”the door was openedâ€”I walked in and said, "I am a police officer, and have four warrants for your father's arrest"â€”Emile said, "Out you go," and knocked me down in the passageâ€”Ferdinand kicked me while I was on the groundâ€”he caught me by my sleeves and tried to drag me to the doorâ€”I shouted for assistanceâ€”the other officers came in, and the prisoners ran into the kitchenâ€”I was kicked on the shoulder-boneâ€”I was examined by the police surgeon.

Cross-examined. Three other constables were watching the houseâ€”they were three or four yards awayâ€”the passage was quite darkâ€”I fell down sideways towards the staircaseâ€”I could not arrest Emile when he struck me on account of his father's violenceâ€”before we went upstairs I told the prisoners they would both be arrested for assaulting me in the execution of my dutyâ€”I left them in charge of two other officers and proceeded upstairs and the old man was brought downâ€”we could not arrest the prisoners on account of their father's violence, and when we got the old man into the street the sons bolted the door so that we could not get in againâ€”next morning the old man was brought before the Magistrate who said that the two sons were to be arrestedâ€”that was not the first time we thought of arresting themâ€”I was struggling with the prisoners in the passage for perhaps five minutesâ€”the gate was closed, and

they had to get over itâ€”I told the doctor that evening that I had been kicked about the shoulder and bodyâ€”I said I did not think I was seriously injuredâ€”he dressed my thumbâ€”at the first hearing before the Magistrate the doctor said, "My attention was not called to any bruises."

Re-examined. There were not enough constables there to take the old man out of the house and arrest the other prisoners as wellâ€”at first I did not show the doctor the bruises, but later they came out.

JAMES LAMBERT (24 Y. R.) I was with Hyde when he went to Tiverton Road to execute the warrants against the prisoners' fatherâ€”I saw the door openedâ€”I walked inâ€”I heard Hyde say he was a police officer, and then there was a scuffleâ€”I saw the prisoners and an old workman in the passageâ€”when I heard the scuffle I rushed into the passage and found Hyde lying on the floor and being dragged to the door by the prisonersâ€”Ferdinand kicked him on the shoulder onceâ€”I assisted to pull the prisoners off him, and they went into the back kitchenâ€”I was in uniform.

Cross-examined. I did not arrest the prisoners then because I went upstairs after the older man, and when we went out with the old man the door was closedâ€”it was our intention to get the old man out first and then arrest the prisonersâ€”the Magistrate was not the first to suggest that the prisoners should be arrested, we were going to apply for a warrant against them, but they attended the Court, and the Magistrate ordered them to be arrestedâ€”Emile lived in Debenham Road, and Ferdinand lived with his fatherâ€”I went into the house about a minute after Hyde; it was not five minutes afterwardsâ€”he did not force his way inâ€”I did not hear any cries or shouts from Hyde after he went inâ€”I did not say at the police court that as soon as Hyde said he was a police officer the prisoners ceased to resistâ€”I said that after I arrived in the passage they continued to drag him towards the doorâ€”I do not suggest that the prisoners assaulted me in any wayâ€”when Hyde said he was a police officer I was about three yards from himâ€”I did not see him struckâ€”I saw him kicked by Ferdinand on the right shoulderâ€”I saw seven or eight planks in the passageâ€”I did not hear them fall.
Re-examined. Hyde was kicked between the shouldersâ€”at the police-court I said, "What made them stop was that they were overpowered."

ARTHUR WHITE (616 Y.) I was with Hyde and Lambert when they went to Tiverton Roadâ€”I saw Hyde go to the door, and heard him say, "I am a police officer and hold a warrant for Ferdinand Czilinskys arrest for non-payment of rates"â€”I heard someone say, "Out you go"â€”I went to the doorâ€”Hyde was inside the passageâ€”Emile knocked him to the floor and then Ferdinand kicked him about the body, and dragged him towards the doorâ€”the prisoners then rushed into the kitchenâ€”Hyde and Lambert went upstairsâ€”the kitchen door was opened by Emile, who had a brick in his hand which I took away from himâ€”Ferdinand took a knife from the table, and said, "I will run it through the first one that puts a hand on me"â€”I said, "If you use the knife I shall use the brick"â€”I heard a struggle upstairs and someone calling for helpâ€”I went up assistance.
Cross-examined. It was Emile who struck Hydeâ€”there was no light

in the hall, but there was in the kitchen, which was shining into the passageâ€”Emile was standing on one side of Hyde when he struck himâ€”Hyde fell down backwards all in a lump towards the staircaseâ€”he was caught by the collar, but we prevented him from being draggedâ€”I did not look on and do nothingâ€”I was in plain clothesâ€”I did not arrest the prisoners then because I went upstairs to assist Lambert, and when we got out into the road the door was closed behind usâ€”I do not remember Lambert saying at the police-court, "When Hyde told them he was a police officer they ceased to resist,"
Re-examined. I think they desisted because we were too many for them.

RICHARD POOLE (14 Y. R.) I was with the last witnesses on December 31st at Czilinsky's houseâ€”I was in uniformâ€”I saw Hyde take his stand at the doorway, which was opened by one of the prisonersâ€”Hyde entered, and shortly afterwards he said, "I am a police officer and hold a warrant for the arrest of your father for the non-payment of rates"â€”one of the prisoners said, "Out you go!"â€”there was a struggle, and Hyde called for assistanceâ€”I entered the passage and found him lying on the floor and Emile pulling at his arm dragging him towards the front door, and Ferdinand was kicking him on his side as far as I could seeâ€”the passage was in darknessâ€”I assisted in getting them off, and they ran into the kitchenâ€”when Hyde and Lambert went upstairs I went into the kitchenâ€”Emile came in with a brickâ€”White took it from himâ€”Ferdinand took up a knife from the table where it was lying with four others and said, "I will put this through the first of you that comes for me"â€”he put it down at his brother's requestâ€”I put the four knives into the drawerâ€”I assisted in getting the old man out of the houseâ€”we did not arrest the other men then because the door was closed.

Cross-examined. Lambert went into the house first after Hyde, then White, and then myselfâ€”I did not see either of the prisoners strike Hyde in the faceâ€”he complained of having been struck when we got outsideâ€”he did not then say anything about being kickedâ€”when the doctor was called in Hyde said he had been kicked about the bodyâ€”the first suggestion that a warrant should be applied for for the prisoners' arrest was made that eveningâ€”the other constables would not have followed Hyde into the house if he had served the warrants without being assaulted, and did not want assistanceâ€”I did not hear him call out, "Come on, I am in."

PATRICK WHITE RATTRAY . I am Divisional Surgeon at Upper Holloway police stationâ€”on December 31st I examined Hydeâ€”he had a cut on his thumb, a blow on his face, and was bleeding from a skin wound on his faceâ€”I examined his back, and found a recent bruise just over the right shoulder bladeâ€”it could have been caused by a kickâ€”there was apparently no great violence.

Cross-examined. He did not complain of having been kicked at first, he did of having been struck in the faceâ€”I cannot say what was the cause of the injury to his noseâ€”if he had received a severe blow on his nose it would not present the appearance half an hour afterwards of having been scratched.
Re-examined. A man's nail might have caused the scratch on the noseâ€”there were distinct signs of a blow on his face, I think not more than one blow.

p.hi: Emile, in his defence on oath, said that he was going home; that he put his hand on the catch of the door, when it was suddenly burst open, and Hyde fell against him; that he did not know he was a constable; that he emphatically denied striking him, but that there was a kind of cuddling set out, and then the other officers came in; that Hyde was in plain clothes; that he did not say he was a police officer; that he was not knocked down, but that in the commotion some wood which was against the wall fell down; that the police did not threaten to arrest him that evening; that he went out that same evening, but that he believed his friend, Mr. Roxam, closed the door when the police went out with his father; that he did not threaten any of the officers with a knife; that there were some knives on the table, and he may have put his hand on them, but he knew he was wrong, and put them down directly.

Ferdinand, in his defence on oath, said that when his brother put his hand on the latch he and Roxam were behind him; that Hyde burst the door open; that a scuffle took place, during which a lot of wood fell down on Hyde, who then commenced pummelling him in the face; that he (Ferdinand) then ran into the scullery and picked up a brick, which a constable in plain clothes took away from him; that he did not strike or kick Hyde; that he did not see his brother strike him; that no one fell down, and that there was no mention by the constables of their having been assaulted.

div1.p: HENRY ROXAM . I am a shop fitter, and on December 31st I was working for Mr. Czilinskyâ€”I was leaving the house about 7 p.m.â€”one of the prisoners followed me to let me out, when someone in plain clothes forced his way in I did not hear him call out, "I am a police officer"â€”I heard him say, "Come on, I am in"â€”we were pushed into the passageâ€”then I saw some constables in uniformâ€”I did not see Emile strike Hyde in the face and knock him downâ€”the passage was darkâ€”I heard some planks fall downâ€”none of us kicked the policemanâ€”we were pushed back into the kitchenâ€”I was held by one of the policemen, and one said to me, "Are you going to pay the money, Mr. Czilinsky?"â€”I said, "I do not know what you are talking about"â€”he said, "Are you going to pay the money, I have four warrants against you?"â€”I said, "What are you holding me for; you come in as if it was a den of thieves, my name is Henry Roxam, and I live at 7, Victoria Road"â€”I went with Mr. Czilinsky to the station, but I was not allowed to go inâ€”on the way there one of the constables said, "You had a laugh at us, and we have had a laugh at you on New Year's Eve."

Cross-examined. I cannot say very well what took place in the passage, because it was darkâ€”if anyone was on the ground I should have fallen over himâ€”in the kitchen one of the policemen said to Emile "I have a good mind to arrest you as well"â€”Emile did rather a foolish thing, he picked up a knifeâ€”I said, "Put the knife down," and the policeman took it off the table and put it in a drawerâ€”Emile did not say, "I will put this knife into the first man that comes."
By the COURT. The old man was not in the least violent when the police were bringing him downstairs or on the way to the station.

rs.hi: of wilfully obstructing the police, and of a common assault.

hi.rs:
Dis
charged on their own recognisances.

div1.p:
215.
ANDREW GEMLICHKA (18)
, Unlawfully soliciting
Charles Robert Fleury to supply certain noxious poisons, intended to be used to procure abortion.

GUILTY .
To enter into recognisances.

216.
HENRY GRAYSON ,
Carnally knowing
Clara Wiggins, aged fourteen years and five months.
NOT GUILTY .

217.
JOHN CHARLES COLLINS alias
DUNDAS , (26),
PLEADED GUILTY to
forging and uttering an order for the payment of Â£50;
also to obtaining by false pretences from
Jeremiah Woodrow and others a hat and other goods with intent to defraud.
Eighteen months' hard labour. â€”

(218)
ESMOND WILLIAM WARD (32), otherwise
WILLIAM WILSON
, to wilful and corrupt perjury. Three previous convictions were proved against him.
Nine months' hard labour, to run concurrently with a sentence which he is now servinq. (See page 330).
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

219.
ALBERT COLLINS (53)
, Forging and uttering an order for the payment of Â£10, with intent to defraud.

p.hi: The evidence is unfit for publication.

div1.p: GUILTY .

220. The said
ALBERT COLLINS
PLEADED GUILTY to
stealing three rings, the property of
John Hutchinson and others.
Judgment Respited.

221.
THOMAS DOWELL (34)
, Feloniously shooting at
Harry Church with intent to do him grievous bodily harm.

HARRY CHURCH . I am a news agent of 10. Alwyne Villas, Canonburyâ€”at 12.15 a.m. on January 2nd, I was with Frederick Maynard, a friend, in Rosebery Avenueâ€”I saw the prisoner come out of a public-house, and told him I should give him a thrashing for carrying on with my wifeâ€”we had an altercation, and he pulled out a revolver and shot at meâ€”I threw him to the ground, and tried to take the revolver awayâ€”a friend

of his then pulled me down upon my backâ€”the prisoner then got up, and ran after my friend and fired at himâ€”I said, "Don't fire at him, he has done nothing to you"â€”he then turned round and fired at me againâ€”both shots hit meâ€”I caught hold of him, held him till the police came, and gave him into custody, and then went to the hospitalâ€”I am an out patient now, but my wounds have healed.

Cross-examined. The altercation lasted three or four minutesâ€”pretty strong language was usedâ€”it is not true that I threw the prisoner to the ground before he fired at meâ€”he pointed the revolver straight at meâ€”three shots were fired altogether.

FREDERICK MAYNARD . I am a commission agent, and live with Churchâ€”I was with him in Rosebery Avenue on the early morning of January 2nd. when we met the prisonerâ€”Church went up to him and told him he would give him a thrashingâ€”they had an altercation, and got to high wordsâ€”they then separated as if to fight and all of a sudden there was a flash and a reportâ€”Church then shouted, "Look out," and I saw the prisoner running towards me, pointing a revolver at meâ€”I ran awayâ€”I heard two other reports, and Church said that he was shotâ€”afterwards the police came up and the prisoner was given into custody.

Cross-examined. I do not remember anything after the flash and the first report, until I heard Church shout, "Look out"â€”I did not see Church close with the prisonerâ€”I cannot say whether he shot at me, my back was turned to him.

JAMES BRASINGTON (65 G). I was on duty in Dyson Street, on January 2nd, at 12.15 a.m., I heard a loud report, and two others a few seconds afterâ€”I ran into Rosebery Avenue and saw the prisoner held by two or three menâ€”the prosecutor said, "He has shot me, lock him up"â€”I took him to the stationâ€”on the way he said. "I put it on him after they knocked me down"â€”he was formally charged, and in reply said. "Would you mind taking notice that I am smothered in mud where they knocked me down"â€”some one in the crowd handed me this revolver (Produced), there were four discharged cartridges in it, and one undischarged.
Cross-examined. The prisoner was very excitedâ€”he was not drunk, but had been drinkingâ€”I know himâ€”as far as I know, he is a respectable man with a good character.

WILFRED ATTLEE . I am House surgeon at St. Bartholomew's Hospitalâ€”about 12.30 a.m., on January 2nd, the prosecutor was brought thereâ€”he had two wounds in front of his chest, one just above the seventh rib, and one in the middle lineâ€”both wounds tracked under the skin, the upper one for about two inches, and the lower one, for about four inchesâ€”the bullets were just under the skin, and were removed the same dayâ€”the wounds are now practically healedâ€”they were both in dangerous positionsâ€”I do not think they struck with great force.

Cross-examined. Both bullets went in an upward direction, after enter
ing the body, and are consistent with the person holding the revolver, being on the ground.
The prisoner, in his defence on oath, said that he was assaulted by Church,

p.hi: and fired three shots into the air to frighten him, but did not aim at him deliberately.

div1.p:
JOHN GRANGER . I am a wood carver of 21, Margaret Street, Clerken-wellâ€”I was with the prisoner on this nightâ€”we were walking home to
gether when Church stopped Dowell, and threatened to do it on him, and attempted to strike himâ€”Dowell then pulled out a revolver and fired three shots at Churchâ€”they were all fired in quick succession, Dowell standing up at the time.

GUILTY .
Six months' hard labour.

222.
WILLIAM CLARK (31)
, Feloniously shooting at
William George James with intent to do him grievous bodily harm.

WILLIAM GEORGE JAMES . I am a foreman painter in the employ of the Corporation of Westminsterâ€”I have known the prisoner several yearsâ€”he used to be employed under me until he went out to South Africa, with the reservistsâ€”he was invalided home, and came to work with me againâ€”his sight was then very bad, and I asked him to arrange to go into another departmentâ€”he was a little upset about it, but we still remained friendlyâ€”on January 3rd, about 1 p.m., I was leaving work, when he asked me to have a drink with himâ€”I refusedâ€”he said, "Have you anything against me"â€”I said, "No, certainly not" and he then fired a revolver at meâ€”he took it from his right hand pocketâ€”I ducked and he missed me, but broke a pane of glassâ€”he then put the revolver away, and brought out some cartridges saying, "Somebody has got to have these"â€”I then went homeâ€”a little later, I saw Clark coming towards my house, and I went to the door and locked itâ€”he knocked three times, but I did not answer it, and he went awayâ€”I gave information to the police on the following Monday, January 5th.

Cross-examined. The prisoner had been at work with me for fifteen days before he was called outâ€”I corresponded with him while he was in South Africaâ€”I have always been on friendly terms with himâ€”I cannot suggest any motive for his firing at meâ€”the pistol did not go off accident
ally, he fired it straight at me.

HENRY JONES (Detective Sergeant B.) On Monday, January 5th, the prisoner was pointed out to meâ€”I told him I was a police officer, and should take him into custody for shooting at Mr. James in the vestry yard on the 3rdâ€”he replied, "There must be some mistake"â€”I took him to the station, and on the way he said, "I am so sorry; I only did it to frighten him; I threw the revolver in the Thames on Sunday morning"â€”in reply to the charge, he said, "I am so sorry; we had been the best of friends; I would not hurt him for the world 'â€”he afterwards told me that the revolver was at his home, and gave me the key of a box in which it wasâ€”I went to the house and found it, and seven cartridges.
Cross-examined. I know that a Mrs. Sampson gave the revolver to Clark as she was afraid of her husband having it in his possession.
The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate: "All I mean to say,
is I never meant to do the man any grievous bodily harm; we never had any words; it was more of a practical joke than anything else; I call no witnesses."

p.hi: The prisoner, in his defence on oath, said that he had served with the colours in India, Egypt, and South Africa; that the revolver was given him by a lady friend to destroy, as she was afraid of it being in her house; that he was about to show it to James who said, "Put that away Bill, it might go off," at the same time pushing his hand, and that when he did so it went off accidentally.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

223.
WILLIAM CLARK (31), was again indicted
for assaulting
William George James.
MR. HOPKINS, for the Prosecution, offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

224.
HENRY FANSHAWE JEWELL (35), and
JOHN SKINNERTON (75),
PLEADED GUILTY to
conspiring to corruptly taking from
George Ashton Â£5 upon account of aiding him to recover a certain stolen dog his property;
also to conspiring to corruptly take from
Albert Basil Orme Wilberforce Â£4 10s., upon account of aiding
Violet Mary Wilberforce to recover a certain stolen dog, her property. SKINNERTON received a good characterâ€”
Nine months' imprisonment on each count to run consecu
tively.
JEWELâ€”
Six months' imprisonment an each count to run consecu
tively.

225.
WILLIAM ROSE (35)
, Committing an act of gross indecency with
Thomas Harris.
NOT GUILTY .

226.
WILLIAM ROSE was again indicted
for committing an abominable offence with
Thomas Harris.
MR. MURPHY, for the prosecution, offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

227.
CHARLES HENRY BLACKMORE (35)
, Stealing three silver cups and a silver cruet, the property of
Daniel George Collins.

p.hi: The prisoner stated that he pawned the goods, but had no intention of converting them to his own use, upon which the Jury found him.

div1.p:
GUILTY . There were several other indictments against him for like offences, and he had been convicted of unlawfully pawning.
Nine months' hard labour.

228.
JOHN TONE (20), and
WILLIAM SHEHAN (20),
PLEADED GUILTY to
having being found by night, armed with loaded revolvers, with intent to break and enter dwelling houses, having both been convicted at Bow Street, on March 24th, 1892. Three other convictions were proved against Tone, and two against Shehan. MR. PURCELL, for Shehan, stated that the Roman Catholic Mission had interfered in his behalf, and that funds were promised to send him to Canada.
Judgment respited. â€”

(229)
ANTHONY RICHARDSON (30)
, to a libel on
Ethel Flux. The prisoner stated publicly that the accusations he had made against the prosecutrix, his mistress were absolutely false.
Six months' imprisonment. â€”
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

(230)
GEORGE HUBERT ELDER (27)
, to stealing Â£85, Â£255, Â£530, Â£200, Â£50, and other sums, amounting to Â£15,000; of
Montague Norman and others, his masters.

MR. HUMPHREYS, for the Prosecution, stated that the prisoner wrote a full confession before his defalcations were known, and that he had done all he could to assist the prosecution, and had given up shares value about Â£2,000.
Eighteen months' hard labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

(231)
JOHN WILLIAMS (82)
, Indecently assaulting
Nellie Florence Jones.

GUILTY .
Six months' hard labour.

232.
DOUGLAS HALE (45) and
ROBERT FELTON (64)
, Conspiring to induce persons to apply for shares in a Company called
Hale, Howitt, and Company, Limited, with intent to defraud. Second count. Conspiring to defraud the said Hale, Howitt, and Company. Other counts, for defrauding other persons.

During the progress of the case the prisoners stated that they would PLEAD GUILTY to the first and second counts, upon which the Jury found a verdict of GUILTY on the first and second counts.
Three convictions were proved against Felton, and one against Hale at this Court in September, 1890. HALEâ€”
Nine months' hard labour.
FELTONâ€”
Three months' hard labour.

233.
ALFRED ARISS alias
BRADSHAW
(52)
PLEADED GUILTY to
burglary in the dwelling-house of
George Payne, and stealing two over-coats and other articles, his property;
also to stealing a bicycle, the property of
Frederick Walter Wright, having been convicted of felony at Clerkenwell on January 3rd, 1899.
Three years' penal servitude.

234.
HENRY JOHN HOLMES ,
Obtaining by false pretences from
Charles John Lavington Clarke and another, Â£1 13s. 7d., Â£12 12s., and Â£4, with intent to defraud.

p.hi: The Court considered that there was no evidence of fraud to go to the Jury and directed a verdict of

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

235.
GEORGE MOORE (23)
, Breaking and entering the shop of
Alex
ander Jones and stealing fifteen watches and other articles, his property.

ALEXANDER JONES . I am a jeweller, of 99, West Green Road, Tottenhamâ€”on January 12th, at 9.30 p.m., I left my shop safely locked upâ€”the next morning at eight o'clock I was sent for by the police, and found the shop door had been forcibly opened, and the police in charge of the placeâ€”I missed a quantity of gold and silver jewellery, some watches, and plated goodsâ€”I identify this pen and watch (Produced), the watch by the name on the movement, the number on the case, and by the glassâ€”these watches are sent out from the factory with flat glasses, and I substituted a best one for it.

PERCY LINTOT (357 N.) I arrested the prisoner at 12.15 a.m. on January 22ndâ€”I found upon him this pen and watch, a pair of gloves, two jemmies, a screw driver, a piece of candle, a box of matches, a knife, and a purse containing 10s. in silver.

JAMES CHANDLER (Detective N.) I examined the prosecutor's premises on the morning of January 13thâ€”an entry had been effected by pushing the catch back of a back window, lifting it, and forcing an iron sheet awayâ€”the kitchen door had also been forced, and another door leading to the shopâ€”I compared the marks on the window and doors with the two jemmies, and they corresponded.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I did not make the marks upon the doors myselfâ€”Mr. Jones was with me when I compared them.
ALEXANDER JONES (Re-examined.) I was with the detective when he compared the marks with the jemmiesâ€”there was no opportunity for anyone to make the marks before I saw them.

GUILTY . He then
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony at Clerken-well on June 6th, 1900, in the name of Sydney Howard. Four other con
victions were proved-against him.
Three years' penal servitude.

236.
CHRISTOPHER FREDERICK EMMOTT (52)
, Forging and uttering an endorsement on an order for payment of Â£12 12s., with intent to defraud.

RICHARD SQUIRE . I am an undertaker of 10, Royal Parade, Chislehurstâ€”in March, 1902, I instructed the prisoner to collect an account of Â£12 12s. for meâ€”I saw him again some time in April, and asked him if he had received the cheque, and he said "No"â€”I then wrote to Messrs. Hore, Patterson, and Co., of 52, Lincoln's Inn Fields, and got a reply from them saying that a cheque had been sent to Mr. Emmott on March 24thâ€”I them put the matter into the hands of the Law Societyâ€”I know the prisoner's
writingâ€”this endorsement on this cheque (Produced) is hisâ€”it is not mineâ€”I never saw the cheque until it was given me by the policeâ€”I did not give the prisoner authority to endorse it.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. We were very friendly at the timeâ€”I have played at billiards with youâ€”it is quite true that I had assigned my business and property to my wifeâ€”I did not tell you to cash the cheque, take your wack, and send the balance to meâ€”there were no costs due to youâ€”I had previously paid you Â£3 10s. for work done, and that included the collecting of this account.

FREDERICK WILLOUGHBY HORES . I am one of the firm of Hore, Patterson, and Co., 52, Lincoln's Inn Fieldsâ€”I remember receiving an account from Mr. Squires for 12 guineas, and there was a question as to the amountâ€”I also remember receiving an application from Mr. Emmott for the money and on March 24th I sent the cheque produced for Â£12 12s. to Mr. Emmottâ€”it is made payable to It. Squires or order, and has been paidâ€”I do not recollect receiving any communication from Mr. Squires, but that may have been done without my knowing it.
Cross-examined. The cheque is endorsed "R. Squires, C. Fred. Emmott."

WALTER SMITH . I am a cashier at the Union Deposit Bank, 17, King William Street, Charing Crossâ€”the prisoner presented this cheque for payment on March 26thâ€”we had not enough money, and I gave him an exchange slip on the London and County Bank, Covent Garden Branchâ€”I cannot say whether the cheque was already endorsed, or whether it was endorsed in my presence.
Cross-examined. I have known you about fifteen yearsâ€”I have never known you do anything dishonest.

JOHN HEARUM . I am a cashier at the London and County Bank, Covent Garden Branchâ€”on March 26th, I remember this exchange slip and cheque being brought to the Bank; I cannot say by whomâ€”I gave the person twelve guineas, and the cheque has since been paid through the bank.

ELIAS BOWER (Detective Inspector.) I arrested the prisoner on February 3rdâ€”I read the warrant to him; he replied, "I understand"â€”shortly afterwards, he said, "I admit endorsing the cheque; I thought I had some sort of authority from Mr. Squires to do so; I also admit I dad not pay the money over to Mr. Squires: I will tell the Magistrate the truth; I cannot dispute the facts; I must trust to his clemency to deal with me."
Prisoner's Defence. "I was instructed by Squires to get the cheque, cash it, take my wack, and send the balance to him."
NOT GUILTY .

237.
ALFRED BECKETT and
KAY LECKNER (13)
, committing an act of gross indecency.
Beckett was also charged with attempting to commit an unnatural offence with Leckner.

BECKETT
GUILTY â€”
Six months hard labour.

LECKNER
NOT GUILTY .

238.
KAY LECKNER was again indicted
for stealing two letters, a cheque for Â£50, and one for Â£4 10s., the property of
Sydney Arthur Topping.

JAMES WALLS (126 City.) On February 8th, about 3 a.m., I was on duty at Bridewell Police Station when the prisoner was brought inâ€”I searched him, and found two cheques on him, one for Â£50 and one for Â£4 10â€”I asked him where he got them from, and he said he found them in a passageâ€”at that time I had had information as to what had happened in Bolt Court.

JONADAB GROTTICK (Detective Officer.) I took the prisoner under remand to the Unionâ€”on the road he said that he and his brother were standing in Bolt Court when his brother suggested opening the letter boxes to see if there were any postal orders in them; that he went upstairs to get a pair of pincers, and then forced open the letter boxes and got the two cheques; that his brother kept the cheque for Â£4 10s., and he had the one for Â£50

SYDNEY ARTHUR TOPPING . I am a commission agent of Bolt Court, Fleet Streetâ€”this cheque for Â£50 is from a client of mineâ€”when I examined my letter box, I found that it had been forced open, and the lock smashedâ€”when I left it the previous evening it was all right.

GUILTY .
Three years' in a reformatory school.
For the case of Edgar Edwards tried on Thursday and Friday, February 12th and 13th, see Surrey cases.

239.
MENDEL PIERNICK (34), and
DORA PIERNICK (28)
, con
spiring to procure
Marjem Lie Gick to become a common prostitute. Second count procuring the said Marjem Lie Gick to become a common prostitute.
MR. HUTTON Prosecuted; Mr. Green Defended.

MENDELâ€”
Two years' hard labour.
DORAâ€”
Six months' in the second division.

240.
ARTHUR DAVIES .
Libel on
William George Jones.

p.hi: MR. C. W. MATHEWS, MR. STEPHENSON, AND MR. MORRIS

div1.p:
During the progress of the case the prisoner withdrew his plea of justifi
cation, and said that he was Guilty.
GUILTY .
To enter into his own recognizances.

p.hi: Before J. A. Rentoul, Esq., K.C.

div1.p:
241.
GEORGE PASSMORE (35)
, Feloniously receiving a gold watch belonging to
Richard Edwards, knowing it to have been stolen.

hi.rs: The Jury, failing to agree, were discharged without giving a verdict, and the Trial postponed to next Session.

div1.p:
242.
MARY ANN MILLER ,
Forging and uttering a receipt for the pay
ment of Â£9, with intent to defraud.

BENJAMIN MEACHAM . I am a French polisher, of 8, Trifina Place, Bow Laneâ€”I was formerly a Reservist in the 18th Hussarsâ€”I was discharged from the Colours on August 10th, 1902, and went to 14, Abbey Street, Plaistow, where the prisoner, who is my aunt, livesâ€”I only stayed a few hoursâ€”on August 11th I decided to leave that address, and told my aunt that letters might come for me, and that she was not to open themâ€”I went to Bow Laneâ€”I did not tell her the addressâ€”about three months after August 11th I went to see my auntâ€”I asked her if she had any letters for meâ€”she showed me these opened envelopesâ€”one contained my discharge, and the other a money order for Â£10â€”the postmarks are November 15th and 17th, and both are addressed to Private B. Meacham, 14, Abbey Street, Plaistowâ€”I told her that she ought not to have opened them, and it was quite likely she would get into trouble over itâ€”she said, "Don't make a fuss about that," and that she had already changed one order for Â£9, and would pay it back at Â£1 a week after Christmas, and that a man came into the shop who said he had been a soldier for fifteen years, and had shown her the way to change the order, and that she had paid Â£4 rent, and bough herself a pair of boots with the moneyâ€”I reported the matter to Aldershotâ€”the signature "Benjamin Meacham" on this order for Â£9 is not mine, nor written with my authorityâ€”it is dated December 1st, so that the inter
view with my aunt must have been subsequentâ€”I never told her that she could use money coming to me.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. You asked me if I had money to lend, and I said noâ€”I told you at the corner public-house that I had no moneyâ€”I never said, "No, but if any money comes you can use it, as I have altered my address," nor anything of the kindâ€”I said there might be letters, and that I did not know what might be in them.
Re-examined. I changed my address because I did not like the placeâ€”I told the prisoner so.

FREDERICK LLOYD . I am a Corporal in the 11th Hussars at Aldershotâ€”I enclosed these Post Office Orders in the envelope produced, on Novem
ber 10th, 1902, and posted it, after writing the address on it, "14, Abbey Street, Plaistow," which is the address entered by the orderly on the Army Formâ€”that is the proper place to enter it.

JESSIE PRIMROSE PATCHELL . I live at 472. Mile End Road, and am an assistant at the Post Office, High Street, Plaistowâ€”I received these advices, and paid the orders produced for Â£10 and Â£9, payable to Benjamin Meachamâ€”the Â£9 order is dated December 1st.
The Prisoner. "That is the young woman who gave me the money."

PRISCILLA HIBBS . I live at 12, Selwyn Road, Plaistowâ€”14, Abbey Street is my propertyâ€”the rent is 9s. 6d. a weekâ€”it was paid by Mr. Miller, the husbandâ€”he got into arrears in the autumn, and sometimes I received a few shillings over the 9s. 6d.â€”at most 2s. 6d. over, never Â£1.

WILLIAM BROWN (Defective Officer.) On January 8th, about 5 p.m., I went with Inspector Nicholls to 14. Abbey Street, Plaistowâ€”I said to the prisoner, "Is your name Mary Ann Miller?"â€”she said, "Yes,"â€”I said "I have a warrant for your arrest for stealing a Post Office Order for Â£9 in November lastâ€”she said, "Yes, I took it, but my boy had told me if I was short of money I could have some, I did not sign it, a man who came into the shop with a pair of old boots did that for me, but I do not know who he is, nor where he lives."

p.hi: The prisoner, in her defence, repeated this statement.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

243. The said
MARY ANN MILLER was again indicted
for stealing a Post Office Order, the property of
Benjamin Meacham, upon which no evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

244.
ARCHIBALD HENRY WATTS (37)
PLEADED GUILTY to
feloni
ously marrying
Daisy Emma Giles, his wife being alive;
also to making a false declaration before the Marriage Registrar.
Nine months' hard labour.

245.
WALTER JAMES WALLIS
PLEADED GUILTY to
unlawfully obtaining credit for Â£114 7s. 10d, Â£90 14s. 1d., and Â£28 8s., without stating that he was an undischarged bankrupt.
Two months' imprisonment in the second division.â€”And

(246)
GEORGE WRIGHT (30) and
JAMES JACKSON (47)
, to stealing three saws and other tools, the goods of
Edward Onslow, and other tools of other workmen.
Twelve months' hard labour each.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

247.
WILLIAM ANGUS JARVIS (40) and
ELIZABETH MUDD (34)
, Unlawfully causing grievous bodily harm to
Martha Calnan.

MARTHA CALNAN . I am the wife of Phillip Calnan, a blacksmith, of 26, Market Buildings, High Street, Shadwellâ€”on January 28th, about 6.30 p.m., I was in my rooms with the door locked, when the two prisoners broke open the door and forced their way inâ€”Jarvis struck me under my right earâ€”I fell down, and was unconscious for some timeâ€”I do not re
member anything more until I was scaldedâ€”my three little children were with meâ€”the eldest is nine years oldâ€”when I came to, the prisoners had goneâ€”I then went for a policeman.
Cross-examined by Jarvis. I did not call you a b----bastard, nor the female prisoner a b----rotten whâ€”I did not take up the tea kettle and scald myself.
MARTHA CALNAN . I am eight "years old, and live with my motherâ€”

I remember the two prisoners bursting our door openâ€”they then knocked mother down, and the woman took the kettle of hot water off the fire and poured it over herâ€”mother yelled out and the two people ran off.
Cross-examined by Jarvis. Mother did not take the kettle off the fir herself.

GEORGE BARTON (61 H.) On the evening of January 28th I was called to Market Buildings, High Street. Shadwellâ€”I found the place a total wreckâ€”a table was turned up in one corner of the room, the place was running with water, and a kettle was in another cornerâ€”the door had been forced openâ€”the prosecutrix had a bad scald on her arm, and another on her foreheadâ€”the prisoners were not in the room when I went there; they were in their own rooms just underneathâ€”the prosecutrix made a state
ment to me, and I arrested themâ€”in their presence she told me that they had forced their way into the room, that the man caught hold of her hair and struck her, and that the woman poured a kettle of boiling water over her.

CHARLES GRAHAM GRANT . I am Police Surgeon of the H Divisionâ€”I saw the prosecutrix about 8 p.m. on January 28thâ€”she was suffering from a scald on her right arm, four inches by three, and a similar injury to her forehead and scalpâ€”she would not entertain the idea of going to the hospital, so I visited her the next morningâ€”I then found her lips swollen and her right eye very much closedâ€”her pulse was 126 to the minuteâ€”I saw her four days ago, and she was then practically wellâ€”she must have suffered great painâ€”if the temperature of the water had been a little higher she would have lost her sightâ€”I do not think her injuries are consistent with her falling down with a kettle.

The prisoners' statements before the Magistrate. Jarvis says, "My daughter can prove I was not in the place; the door was open when I went there; I did not touch the lady." Mudd says, "She scalded herself."

GUILTY . JARVISâ€”
Twelve months' hard labour.

MUDDâ€”
Two years' hard labour.

248.
FREDERICK JOHN BARTON (39)
, Feloniously marrying
Elizabeth McPherson during the life of his wife.

HARRY TARBARD (Constable R.). I arrested the prisoner on December 18th, at the Royal Arsenal, Woolwich, where he was employedâ€”Eliza
