beth McPherson instituted the proceedings against himâ€”I knew the prisoner previouslyâ€”when I arrested him, he said, "I did not know my wife was alive, or I should not have married again"â€”this is the certi
ficate of his marriage. (Dated November 14th, 1885, at the Parish Church, Lenham, Kent.)â€”his name on the certificate of the second marriage, which was on September 6th, 1902, is given as Frederick John Barnes, he did not give any reason for having taken that nameâ€”I told him I should take him into custody for feloniously marrying in the name of Barnes; he said his name was Barton.
Cross-examined. He had been employed at the Arsenal about three years in the same nameâ€”I believe he has been separated from his wife for fourteen years.

ELIZABETH ELSE . I live at Lenham in Kent, and am the sister of the prisoner's wifeâ€”I was present on November 14th, 1885, when they were married, and I signed the registerâ€”they lived together for about twelve months at Ashfordâ€”at the time of the marriage he was twenty-three years old, and was a carterâ€”one Saturday my sister came home for a holiday, he was supposed to come later, but did not do so, and we heard that he had deserted herâ€”my sister lived in London for eight or nine years after thatâ€”she has one boyâ€”he was ten months old when she came to usâ€”she now lives at my home, with me and my motherâ€”she was a housekeeper to three ladiesâ€”we have lived at Lenham all our livesâ€”on November 17th, 1902, the prisoner called at my mother's cottage as another manâ€”I recognised him, but did not tell him soâ€”he inquired for my sisterâ€”I said, "Which one?"â€”he said, "Fanny"â€”he asked me if I had ever heard of my sister going back to live with her husband againâ€”he did not give any nameâ€”I said I had never heard her say anything about itâ€”he asked if my sister knew what name he had been married inâ€”I said I did not knowâ€”he said he thought they had better have a separation.

Cross-examined. My sister took the housekeeper's place about twelve months after the prisoner left herâ€”she often came down to see us while she was living in Londonâ€”I do not think they got on well togetherâ€”I do not know the reason of his leaving herâ€”I never saw him from the time he left his wife till November, 1902, to my knowledge.
NOT GUILTY .

249.
EMILY FRENCH (26)
PLEADED GUILTY to
unlawfully concealing the birth of her male child by a secret disposition of the dead body.
Three days' imprisonment.

250.
EDWARD CHRISTENSEN (21),
PLEADED GUILTY to
stealing two candlesticks the goods of
Adolphus Bridges in his dwelling house;
also a clock case, a watch, and a coronation medal, the goods of
Harry Beadles;
also to stealing a clock, the goods of
Caroline Keath;
also to stealing a clock, the goods of
Alexander Haigh, in his dwelling house.
Eighteen months' hard labour.

251.
GEORGE ROLAND WILLIAMS otherwise
JAMES TERRY (39),
Forging and uttering a receipt for Â£1 18s. 10d., with intent to defraud.

HENRY COLLIER . I was formerly in the 23rd Royal Welsh Fusiliersâ€”I am deafâ€”I was last year in Cardiff Workhouse and am nowâ€”the prisoner was "luny" masterâ€”for the first time last year, I become entitled, under some new regulations, to a pension of 4d. a day, and received Form A The particulars and description of the pension) to be filled upâ€”I got another

pauper named James to fill it upâ€”I signed the declaration at the endâ€”"I am the above named pensioner"â€”the words "Workhouse, Cardiff," are scratched throughâ€”I told James to put that as the place of paymentâ€”I did not write "Post Office, Canton, Cardiff, till called for"â€”I took it to the prisoner at the receiving ward, and asked him to get it signed for me by the doctorâ€”he said he wouldâ€”I called for it some time afterwards, and it was signed by Dr. Leeâ€”the prisoner said I should have nothing till Octoberâ€”I posted the paper after he returned it to metâ€”I did not sign "Henry Collier" on Exhibit Bâ€”I have not seen this paper before (This was a money order, stamped July 15th, 1902, for Â£1 19s, 1d., issued at the Wrexham Regimental District Pay Office, and payable at the Post Office, Canton, Cardiff.)â€”I know nothing of this application (Exhibit D), for transfer of payment from Cardiff, to the S.E. District Money Order Office, London, dated August 12th; I did not sign itâ€”I never got that order for Â£1 18s. 10d.

Cross-examined by the prisoner. I brought you Exhibit A about 11 a.m.â€”I do not remember if I was present when the doctor signed itâ€”I have a nephew named Albert Cliffordâ€”I did not converse with him about the guardians stopping my pension for my maintenanceâ€”I joined the Welsh Fusiliers in 1857â€”I got James to write to the Paymaster when I did not receive my pension in Octoberâ€”I waited for the paper in the receiving ward with othersâ€”I was working, and had to get back to my workâ€”you brought it back to me in the afternoonâ€”the only thing I noticed then was the doctor's signature at the bottom, that is all I looked for.

GEORGE PLEWS . I am a clerk to the Guardians at Cardiffâ€”the prisoner entered on his duties as male lunatic attendant at the Cardiff Workhouse on June 23rd, 1902â€”he sent a letter of resignation dated July 12th, which was received on July 13thâ€”he received a letter from the guardians to attend a meeting to inquire into the genuineness of his testimonialsâ€”he went off without attendingâ€”he said he had been an Army pensioner, and had a Victoria Crossâ€”Exhibit E is a book kept in the lunatic ward, in which it was the prisoner's duty to make entriesâ€”I know his writingâ€”the words on Exhibit A "Post Office, Canton, Cardiff," which have been substituted for the words "Workhouse, Cardiff," are the prisoner's writing, as well as the words, "Henry Collier" in Exhibit B, the money order for Â£1 19s. 1d., the words "South Eastern District, London, S.E.," at the back of it, and the words in Exhibit C, the application for transfer of the repay
ment of the order, "Post Restante, South-Eastern District, London," and the signature, "Henry Collier"â€”I cannot pass an opinion on the signature "Henry Collier," to the receipt on Exhibit D. '

Cross-examined. I am not an authority on handwritingâ€”I see a great deal of itâ€”your wages would have been Â£1 9s. 8d. to the time you leftâ€”you did not get anyâ€”the wages are paid monthlyâ€”the letter of resignation was left on the Sunday when you went off.

WILLIAM ROWLAND LEE . I am Medical officer of the Cardiff Unionâ€”I signed Exhibit A of July 12th, 1902â€”Williams, who was lunatic attendant brought the form to meâ€”he was with Collier, an inmateâ€”he asked me to fill up the bottom part of it, as I usually do with a number of pensions which

are paid to inmatesâ€”when I had signed it I handed it back to Williams, under the impression that it was to be given to the Relieving Officer, as is usually doneâ€”there was no alteration in it when I handed it back to Wil
liams.
Cross-examined by the prisoner. I came about 1 p.m.

MAJOR HENRY WESTENRA CARDEN . I am Paymaster at Wrexham for the 12th Fusiliersâ€”I sent out Exhibit A on July 11thâ€”I received it back on July 14th, filled up, and on July 10th my clerk made out the money order for the Â£1 19s. 1d., and I posted itâ€”it is the regular Army money order, showing the amount due to Collier on his pension of 4d. a dayâ€”this was the first pension he drew, and covered the time from June 5th to September 30th, the end of that quarterâ€”I cannot exactly say what the prisoner said with regard to the words "Post Office, Canton, Cardiff," but I remember he made a statement.
Cross-examined. The prosecutor has not received any of this pensionâ€”he has received some subsequently I believe.
Re-examined. The Guardians do not stop pensions under 8d. a day coining to paupers.

ALICE STANLEY . I am the wife of Thomas Stanley, and am a clerk at the Canton Branch Post Office, Cardiffâ€”about August 2nd, 1902,1 received a letter from Henry Collier from Wrexham, and a notice from the South Eastern District Office in London, that a Post Office Order was to be sent there to be called forâ€”the letter would be sent to the Postmaster with the notice enclosedâ€”the application for transfer, Exhibit C, passed through my handsâ€”the Order, Exhibit B, is for Â£1 19s. 1d.â€”on August 8th I issued Exhibit D, which is an Order for the payment of Â£1 18s. 10d., payable to Henry Collier at the South Eastern District Post Office, Londonâ€”I addressed it adding, "Wait till called for," and sent it to the S.E. District Post Office London, in accordance with the regulation.

EMMELINE AVIS OLIVER . I am a clerk at the S.E. District Post Office, Londonâ€”the words in Exhibit C, "Canton, Cardiff," "myself," "South Eastern District," and "Wrexham," at the bottom are my writingâ€”it passed through my hands, but I do not recollect the circumstances.
Cross-examined. I have seen someone like you at the office.

GRACE MITCHELL . I am a clerk in the S.E. District Post Office, Borough Road, Londonâ€”I cashed the P.O. Order, Exhibit D, for Â£1 18s. 10d. on August 12thâ€”it bears my initialsâ€”I have no recollection about it.
EDWIN PRESTON (Police Inspector I)). I know the prisonerâ€”I saw him in London on July 14th and August 13th last.

ALBERT WARD (Detective Sergeant.) About 10 a.m. on January 9th I arrested the prisoner at East Dulwichâ€”I read the warrant to himâ€”it was for forging a receiptâ€”he said, "I know nothing at all about it"â€”when Major Carden was giving evidence at the Police Court the prisoner asked the Magistrate if he might see the formâ€”he took it in his hand and said, "The line 'Post Office. Canton, Cardiff, till called for,' is my writing"â€”it was then handed back.
Cross-examined. I visited 14, Berkeley Street, in Novemberâ€”I have been

told that another officer visited there, but not in reference to this caseâ€”I have since visited it several timesâ€”14, Berkeley Street, is the address where you lived onceâ€”I have not tampered with, but I have opened letters addressed to youâ€”I had reasons for doing so since you were in custodyâ€”I spoke to a Deaconess about your characterâ€”you are an impostor.

Prisoner, in his defence, said that the words "Post Office, Canton, Car
diff, till called for," were his writing, but at the prosecutor's request, who said, "You sign it, I am no scholar, or else the Guardians will take my pension away," that he afterwards found out that when he was out for his half-day that the prosecutor could have got the pension; that the Guardians owed him Â£2 13s. 4d., including his hotel expenses in Cardiff, and that he was not likely to leave that and come to London for Â£1 18s. 10d., that he was innocent; and that the money was agreed between Collier and his nephew to be given to the nephew.

GUILTY . He then
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony at this Court in September, 1898. Five other convictions were proved against him.
Five years' penal servitude.

252.
STEPHEN WILLINGTON (51)
, For a libel upon
Hugh Evan Robinson.

JOHN HENRY STOBRAD BRADLEY . I live at 20, Auckland Streetâ€”I have been in business four to five years as a steel makerâ€”I made an agree
ment with the prisoner to sell a patent, dated September 29th, 1902â€”I withdrew from it after working a week, making drawings and tracings, and getting only 9s. the prisoner having Â£50â€”I received this letter of Decem
ber 26th, 1902â€”it is in the prisoner's writingâ€”(This was marked "Pri
vate," addressed "Dear Bradley," and stated, "I was pained on seeing you with Robinson this day"."Robinson I shall ever look upon as a dirty criminal"."he has done dirty business for some years" "I know he has done eighteen months for forgery," and "you now nothing of this class of vermin.")

Cross-examined. After the agreement I went to the prisoner's place day by day and wasted my timeâ€”Robinson did most of the writing, and if it had not been for Robinson I should have thought that he was an honest man, till he told me he was a scampâ€”Robinson volunteered to do my correspondence, and I thanked himâ€”he told me the prisoner is a scamp, so he is, and if he gets outside I am waiting, and it will be far more serious; he has been lodging all over London, getting Â£50 here, and Â£50 there, the man has been a scamp and an adventurer all his lifeâ€”Robinson was not my servantâ€”there was no quarrelâ€”I never gave the prisoner a bad word.

p.hi:
submitted that the letter was privileged, being written by per
sons between whom there was a common interest and not maliciously. The
held that the question whether the letter was a libel, was for the Jury The prisoner then, on the advice of his Counsel said he was Guilty of writing the letter.

div1.p:
GUILTY .
To enter into recognisances.

253.
WILLIAM PHILLIP FORD (40)
, Feloniously wounding
Robert Frankland with intent to do him grievous bodily harm.

ROBERT FRANKLAND . I am a ship broker, and live in the Boroughâ€”on Christmas Eve, between 8 and 9, I was in the Winchester Arms, Suffolk Street, Borough, and saw the prisonerâ€”he was in one bar and I in anotherâ€”he kept saying that he could get as much in a day as I could in a monthâ€”he came round to the bar I was in and struck me with a knife, and I was in the hospital six weeks and four daysâ€”I had not pushed him or knocked him downâ€”I never had a word with him in my life, and I have known him for years.

Cross-examined. He accused me of working cheaper than himâ€”I did not use bad language to himâ€”I did not ask him to come outside and fightâ€”I do not believe I struck himâ€”I had had a drop, but I was not drunkâ€”I swear I did not knock him downâ€”I did not go back into the bar, nor did he follow meâ€”I had a barrow outsideâ€”he did not say, "Don't come rushing at me, because I have got a knife, and will defend myself"â€”I did not attack him at all.

LOUISA MILBANK . I am single, and live at 22, Kemp's Courtâ€”on Christmas Eve I was standing at my stall opposite the Winchester Arms, and saw Fordâ€”Mr. Frankland touched him and he fell down, and got up and went into the barâ€”I saw Ford-go to his barrow and get a knife, and I saw Frankland on the ground bleedingâ€”I saw a knife in Ford's hand, but did not see him use it.

Cross-examined. I saw them quarrelling outside the public-houseâ€”Frankland followed him into the public-house, but went into a different barâ€”I do not know what took place insideâ€”Ford struck the first blowâ€”no one else was in the passageâ€”I do not know whether Frankland rushed at Ford, because I turned to serve a customer.

JOHN MARTIN (87 B.) I was on duty near the Winchester Armsâ€”between 8 and 9 o'clock I saw a great crowdâ€”Frankland took his shirt out from his trousers, and I saw part of his bowels hanging outâ€”I said, "Who did this?"â€”the prisoner said, "I did it with this knife"â€”I took him in custody.

HERBERT WILLIAM BROWN . I am house surgeon at Guy's Hospitalâ€”I examined Frankland about 5.15â€”he had a very dangerous wound, such as might have been inflicted with this knifeâ€”he is going on all right.

Cross-examined. It has practically healedâ€”I cannot say how he was as to drink as the wound would destroy any effects of alcoholâ€”the prisoner said before the Magistrate, "I did it in the height of passion."

JOHN MARTIN (Re-examined.) The prisoner has always borne a good character as a peaceable manâ€”Frankland was perfectly sober, but I did not see him that night before he was woundedâ€”when the prisoner was charged at the police station he said, "I did not intend to do him bodily harm; I said, "Will you go away.'"

p.hi: The prisoner, in his defence, stated upon oath that Frankland knocked him down, but he took no notice of that, and went on opening oysters for

somebody, and then went into the Winchester Arms, where Frankland called him bad names; that he went out again, and was opening oysters, when Frankland made a rush at him by his barrow, and he said,"Go away, I have a knife in my hand," but that Frankland plunged on the knife by the side of the barrow, and that it was not done in the house.

rs.hi: of unlawfully wounding, with great provocation.

div1.p:
254.
JAMES EWING (46)
, Stealing a stock, a set of twenty-eight bits, and other articles, the property of
Bernard Stephen McAteer.

BERNARD STEPHEN MCATEER . I am a carpenter, of 2, Huban Road, Fulham, and I work for Mr. Harknell, Meridith Road, Barnesâ€”on January 7th, about 4.30 p.m., I locked up the workshop and left my tools insideâ€”at 7.45 a.m., I went to the shop and found the door broken in and some tools scattered aboutâ€”these tools (Produced) are mineâ€”they were missing from the workshop, and I went to the Putney Police Station and identified themâ€”their value is Â£3.

Cross-examined by the prisoner. I told the Magistrate that I left some of the tools on the bench and some in a basket, the majority were in the basketâ€”whoever took them must have taken them from the basketâ€”I do not think that anybody on the job took themâ€”nobody went into the workshop just as I was leavingâ€”I did not see you there on this dayâ€”I said at the police station that I borrowed the bag and a rule of a navy, but I said I was responsible for them.

EUSTACE GOLDSMITH (608 7). About 6.30 p.m. on January 7th, I was in Lower Richmond Road, Putney, in plain clothes, off dutyâ€”I saw the prisoner carrying a sack on his backâ€”as I passed him I happened to brush against him, and he gave me rather a startled look, which aroused my suspicionsâ€”I followed him to a urinal in High Street, Putney, where I saw him transferring some tools from the bag to his pocketâ€”I put several questions to him as to his possession of the tools, and his answers were un
satisfactoryâ€”I found him about a mile from the workshopâ€”I asked him if the tools belonged to him; he said, yesâ€”I took him to the station and charged him with unlawful possessionâ€”on the way there, he said, "Look here, governor, it is no use my telling you any lies, I will tell you the truth The tools dropped from a cart in the Lower Richmond Road, and I picked them up"â€”that was about half a mile away, it was not between Meredith Road and the prisonerâ€”first he said his name was Green, at the station he said it was Frederick Webbâ€”I think his proper name is Ewing.

Cross-examined. I live about five minutes away from where I first saw youâ€”it was dark then but I could see your faceâ€”it is a well lighted thorough-fareâ€”you put the tools back into the bag at the urinalâ€”it is fairly well lightedâ€”it is in a busy thoroughfare, but you were the only one in the urinal while I was thereâ€”this is the bag you were carryingâ€”you told me that Sergeant Dolling, who used to be at Wimbledon, knew you well by the name of "Squash."
ALEXANDER FULLERTON (Detective V.) About 11 o'clock on January

8th, I saw the prisoner at the South Western Police Court, where he was charged with unlawful possession of some toolsâ€”he was discharged, and I told him I should take him into custody for breaking and entering a work-shop in Meredith Road, and stealing the toolsâ€”he replied, "I picked them up in the Upper Richmond Road"â€”I said, "Upper Richmond Road?" he said, "Near Barnes"â€”I took him to the station, he made no reply to the charge.
Cross-examined. I have not found anyone to say that you were in Barnes on that dayâ€”I have evidence to show that you have been in Barnes during the last three months.

The prisoner, in his defence on oath, said that he saw the bag drop off a cart in Richmond Road; that he picked it up and threw it over his shoulder; that he then went into the urinal, and took one or two things out of the bag to see what was in it, when the constable arrested him; he admitted that he had been convicted in 1894 of unlawful possession, and sentenced to nine months' hard labour.

GUILTY .â€”He then
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony at Kingston-on-Thames on October 16th, 1894, and four other convictions were proved against him.
Twelve months' hard labour.

255.
ALFRED PINK (32) and
GEORGE ADE (29),
PLEADED GUILTY
to
feloniously attempting to steal from a post office letter box, certain post letters the property of the
Postmaster-General;
also to maliciously deposit
ing upon the said letter box a certain noxious substance likely to injure the said box, Pinkâ€ having been convicted of felony on August 14th. 1901, at South London Sessions, and Ade at the same court on January 8th, 1902 PINK,
Eighteen months' hard labour â€”ADE,
Nine months' hard labour.

256.
STEPHEN HUNT BRUNSDEN ,
Publishing a libel concerning
John Haggis, to which he pleaded a justification.
The prosecutor not appearing, MR. GANZ, for the prosecution, offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

257.
ALBERT FISHER (22)
, Stealing one dozen boxes of matches and two cakes of soap, the property of
William Gilbert Yates.

WILLIAM GILBERT YATES . I am an oilman of 9, Chalmont Road, Toot
ingâ€”I have no shopâ€”I rent a coach-house in Norman Road, where I keep my vanâ€”it was quite safe on January 23rdâ€”the next day I found all the place in confusion, and several articles missingâ€”I informed the policeâ€”these matches and soap (Produced) are my propertyâ€”I identify the matches by the date, "1st July, 1903"â€”similiar matches and soap are supplied throughout the trade, you can buy the same at any oil shopâ€”the value of the articles produced is sixpenceâ€”3s. worth of goods were stolen altogetherâ€”the door of the coach-house was only fastened with string.
ROBERT WILLIAMSON (Detective-B.) At 10.15 a.m. on January 24th, I received information of a robbery and went to the prosecutor's coach-house

and found the place in confusionâ€”the same day I saw the prisoner at Wimbledon Police Stationâ€”eleven boxes of matches and two cakes of soap were found on him, which the prosecutor identifiedâ€”he was charged and made no reply.
By the COURT. Yates told me that there were other things missed, but only the things produced were found upon the prisoner.
GEORGE HILL (38 V. R.) At 8.15 a.m., on January 23rd, I arrested the prisoner, and took him to the station.
NOT GUILTY .

258.
ALBERT FISHER (22), was again indicted
for stealing a shirt, the property of
Annie Bushill.

ANNIE BUSHILL . I am married, and live at 9, High Path, Mertonâ€”this shirt (Produced) is mineâ€”on January 2nd, I hung it on the clothes line at the back of my houseâ€”the next morning I missed it, and went and told Mr. Hyde, a pawnbrokerâ€”I went there again on the 5th, and saw itâ€”its value is 2s. 6d.â€”I never saw the prisoner.

ALBERT GOLD . I am a labourer of 113, High Street. Mertonâ€”on Janu ary 3rd, I saw the prisoner near the Grove Hotelâ€”he asked me to buy a pawn-ticket for a shirt for 3d. as he wanted to get some foodâ€”I bought itâ€”on the 5th I tendered the ticket at Mr. Hyde's, but he told me the shirt was stolen, and refused to part with itâ€”I have known the prisoner by sight for twelve months, but have not known his name long.

JAMES FOSTER . I live at 170, High Street, Merton, and am manager to Mr. Hyde, a pawnbrokerâ€”on January 3rd, I took this shirt in pawn for 1s.â€”I cannot identify the person who pawned itâ€”on the 5th, Gold tendered the ticket, and wanted to take it out, but I had had intimation that it had been stolen, and refused to part with it.

GEORGE HILL (38 V. R.). On January 23rd, I arrested the prisonerâ€”I told him I should take him into custody on suspicion of stealing a shirt from off the line at 9, High Path, Mertonâ€”he said, "I did not steal the shirt; I expect the wind blowed it off the line, and I picked it up in the allotments; I pawned it at Mr. Hyde's for a shilling"â€”after being charged, he said, "I sold the ticket to Goldie for four pence."
NOT GUILTY .

259.
JOSEPH GRIZARD (35)
, Breaking and entering the shop of
Norton Courlander, and stealing a gold bracelet and other articles, his property.
MR. BIRON Prosecuted; MR. CHARLES MATHEWS and MR. GREEN Defended The COURT considered that there was no case to go to the Jury.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Before J. A. Rentoul, Esq., K.C.

div1.p:
260.
GEORGE PARSONS (29)
PLEADED GUILTY to
carnally knowing
Sophia Jane Plumb, a girl between thirteen and sixteen years of age.
Dis
charged on his own recognisances.

261.
JOHN ANTHONY ALDERSLEY (63)
, Feloniously setting fire to a certain dwelling house, a person being then therein.

hi.rs: On the evidence of Dr. Scott, the medical officer at Brixton Prison, the Jury found that the prisoner was insane and unfit to plead.
To be detained during Sis Majesty's pleasure.

div1.p:
262.
EDGAR EDWARDS (44)
was indicted for and charged on the Coroner's inquisition, with the wilful murder of
John Darby. (The prisoner refused to plead, and the Court ordered a plea of
NOT GUILTY to be entered for him.)
MR. MUIR and MR. A. GILL Prosecuted; MR. PERCIVAL HUGHES and Mr.

ALICE MAUD GOODWIN . I live at 19, Elstead Road, Rodney Road and am the wife of James Goodwinâ€”I have known the prisoner just on five years by the name of Glanvilleâ€”he came to our house on Friday, November 28thâ€”some years had elapsed since I had seen himâ€”he asked me if my husband was inâ€”I said he was not, but if he called later he would beâ€”he said he had come to see if he could do me and my husband a good turnâ€”he did not then say what it wasâ€”he came again that evening about nineâ€”my husband was at home thenâ€”he told my husband in my presence that he had come to see if we would go and manage a business for himâ€”my husband said that he would, and asked him what" sort of a business it wasâ€”the prisoner asked my husband if he could get him a sash-weight which he wanted to sway the door at York Road, Batterseaâ€”he did not then tell us where he livingâ€”I did not see him oil November 29th, but on Sunday, November was 30th, he came about 8.30 a.m.â€”he talked over the matter of the business he was going to buyâ€”he did not tell us then where it wasâ€”he stayed all day, and had breakfast, dinner, and tea with usâ€”he read the paper till it got late, when he asked my husband if we could make it convenient for him to stop all night, as he had lost the last 'bus to Victoria Parkâ€”I agreed, and I laid a bed down on the front room floor for himâ€”next morning, December 1st, we got up and had a wash, and then had breakfast together, and the prisoner asked my husband if he would mind me pawning his umbrella as he was short of cash and he wanted a clean collar and a shave before going to the bank, as he could not get any money there before 10 amâ€”I took the umbrella and pawned it at Thompson's in East Street for 1s. 6d.â€”I bought the prisoner a collar and brought the rest of the money and the pawn ticket back and gave them to my husband, who gave them to the prisonerâ€”this is the ticket (Produced)â€”I used the name of Fowler when pawning the umbrellaâ€”my husband asked the prisoner if the sash-weight which he had got for him would do, and the prisoner said, "Yes, it will do nicely"â€”I saw it wrapped up in paperâ€”at 9 a.m., as he was leaving, he asked us if we knew Wyndham Road, and we said "Yes"â€”he told us to meet him at the corner of Wyndham Road at 11.30, and if we should see him with a gentleman we were not to speak to him until he spoke to usâ€”he then went out, taking the weight with himâ€”we went to the corner of Wyndham Road at 11.30, and

waited till 12.5, when we see the prisoner coming from 22, Wyndham Roadâ€”he had a white apron on, and his shirt sleeves rolled upâ€”he said he was very sorry he had kept us waiting, but he had been running about settling the matter with Mr. Darbyâ€”we went with him to the shop, No. 22, he took us in by the front door, and asked us what we thought of itâ€”my husband said he thought the shop was all right, but that it was in a rough neighbourhoodâ€”we stayed about ten minutes, when the prisoner told us we had better go back and see to my baby, have some dinner, and get back by 1 or 1.30â€”we left the shop about 12.15 and returned about 1.15, but could not get inâ€”we tapped at the door, but got no answerâ€”we waited about ten minutes when we saw the prisoner coming from the Camberwell Road end of Wyndham Roadâ€”he passed the Albany Roadâ€”he let us into the shop by the back door, and then through a little scullery into the shop parlourâ€”lie told us to get our things off, and see about getting into the shopâ€”he lent my husband 30s. to get his things out of pawn, and 2s. 6d. and gave him the pawn ticket to get the umbrella which I had pawnedâ€”we opened the shop between 1.50 and 1.55, and kept it open until 6 p.m.â€”I think the prisoner stopped in the parlour all the afternoonâ€”at six o'clock he told my husband to shut the shop, as he thought he would close earlier that day being the firstâ€”we all three went away togetherâ€”he shook hands with us, and told us to be there about 7.45 next morning, and then he went over to the other side of the roadâ€”next day, December 2nd, we went there again about 7.45 a.m.â€”the prisoner let us inâ€”we kept the shop open all day till 10 p.m.â€”when we left the prisoner let us outâ€”that was the order of events each day until the 10thâ€”on that day the prisoner let us in in the morningâ€”he went out between 9 and 9.30 a.m., and said if any travellers called they were to leave their lists and prices, and he would be back about eleven, but he never came back any moreâ€”I do not know where he went to liveâ€”I do not know the address 89, Church Road, Leytonâ€”during the ten days that we were at the shop we never went upstairs, as the prisoner told us not to, on December 1st, as the Darby's furniture was locked up thereâ€”I remember Mrs. Baldwin coming on December 3rd between 6 and 7 p.m.â€”the prisoner had told us earlier in the day that Mr. Darby was supposed to be coming that evening and if anybody called to tell them soâ€”when Mrs. Baldwin came I went into the shop parlour and heard a conversation between her and the prisonerâ€”I remember a pony and a cart and a van coming to the shopâ€”my husband went and go to themâ€”this document, dated December 8th, is the agreement and terms on which we were engaged by the prisoner in the name of Louden he said he was going to trade as William Thomas Loudenâ€”I saw him write the document.

Cross-examined. When the prisoner called on us he was renewing an old friendshipâ€”there did not appear to be an air of mystery about the businessâ€”he told us he was buying a business, and it was to be settled on December 1stâ€”it did not seem extraordinary to me that a man who said he was buying a business should be in need of 1s. 6d. and want to pawn an umbrella, because he said he had run short of cash and could not get to the bank until ten o'clockâ€”Mr. Darby's name was not over the shopâ€”I think

the name "Pearce" was upâ€”the prisoner made no secret of Darby's existence or of his having been the proprietor of the shopâ€”he mentioned Darby's name quite openly, and said he was buying the business of himâ€”when the prisoner was staying at our house he was reading Mrs. Hartopp's case to my husbandâ€”at the shop he was writing letters in the shop parlour most of the timeâ€”I do not know what he was writingâ€”he seemed to do a good deal of writingâ€”I did not notice anything about his demeanourâ€”he was always pacing up and down and was extremely restlessâ€”it did not strike me as extraordinary when he told us we were not to speak to him when we met him if there was a man talking to himâ€”I have not had a business to manage before, I have served in business placesâ€”he only slept at our place one nightâ€”we went to bed about elevenâ€”I did not hear anything of him till next morningâ€”he slept downstairs in the front roomâ€”I did not notice a blood stain on the shop ceilingâ€”we could have gone upstairs if we had wanted toâ€”we were left alone at the shop a great part of the timeâ€”the prisoner did not, on one occasion leave us to lock up the shopâ€”we did not lock it up once and leave by the back doorâ€”customers were coming in and out all dayâ€”several of them asked for Mr. Darbyâ€”he had been carrying on the business almost up to the day we went thereâ€”the prisoner did not seem anxious when people asked for Darbyâ€”my husband took a great part in the management of the businessâ€”I do not know if he took any part in moving some furnitureâ€”I know he went and got a van and took it round to the side door, but I cannot say what was packed in it, because I was in the shopâ€”he helped to load it, and he told me when he returned that he had driven away with itâ€”he did not tell me he had driven it to Leytonâ€”he said "he had driven it to Whitechapel Churchâ€”he was afterwards sent for to meet the prisonerâ€”if the prisoner was about he would now and again pop in and out and try to serve a customerâ€”he was not very successfulâ€”I do not know if my husband helped to fetch any furniture from upstairsâ€”I remember on December 9th locking up the shopâ€”the prisoner went out that evening, and said to my husband, "Lock up, and bring me the key to East Street, Walworth."

Re-examined. I never knew whether the prisoner had a banking accountâ€”I do not know if he did any paying in or drawing out of the bank while we were at his shopâ€”I never saw any cheque-bookâ€”I never noticed any
thing peculiar about him apart from his restlessness and he was always like that.

JAMES GOODWIN . I live at 19, Elsted Streetâ€”I remember seeing the prisoner there on November 28th in the eveningâ€”he said he had a shop at Battersea and another business at Camberwell, and that he had come to do me and my wife a bit of good if I liked to be his managerâ€”nothing was settled that night, but he said, "Jimmy," you might get me a weight, I want it for a door at the shop at Battersea,"â€”he did not say any road at Batterseaâ€”he said he wanted a weight with a hole in it to hold a cordâ€”I got him one of Mr. Holmes in Porter Street, on November 29th (A sash-weight of 5 1/2 lbs. was produced)â€”the prisoner promised to call that day, but he did not do soâ€”he came next day, Sundayâ€”he stayed with us all day and also for the nightâ€”I and my wife agreed to manage the shop for himâ€”on

the Monday morning he said, "Have you got the weight? I want it this morning"â€”he took it, and said, "Do you know where Wyndham Road Camberwell, is?"â€”I said, "Yes"â€”he said, "You and your wife meet me there at 11.30, and if you see me with a gentleman do not speak to me un less I speak to you"â€”he did not examine the weightâ€”it was wrapped in paperâ€”we met him at the corner of Wyndham Road about 12.5, and went with him to the shopâ€”we remained there two or three minutesâ€”we did not go into any other roomâ€”my wife and I went home and had some dinner and returned at 1.30â€”the shop was closedâ€”we waited about ten minutes, when the prisoner came from the Camberwell Road directionâ€”he took us round to the side and let us in, and said, "Get your things off and open the shop"â€”we opened at about 1.45â€”I had my working clothes onâ€”he said, "Can't you make yourself a little respectable"â€”I said I had no money to get my things out of pawnâ€”he said, "Well, I will lend you a sovereign"â€”he went to pull out a sovereign and said, "You had better have 30s."â€”he sent me to get my clothes, and gave me a ticket to get an umbrella out of pawn for himâ€”the business was to be carried on as "W. T. Louden"â€”we continued to manage it from December 1st to 10thâ€”we only went into the shop and shop parlourâ€”we never went upstairs, because the prisoner gave us instructions not to do so as all the things were locked upâ€”I remember Mrs. Baldwin calling on December 3rdâ€”on that day before he went out the prisoner said to me, "If anyone calls and asks for Mr. Darby say he will be here between six and seven to-night"â€”on December 5th the prisoner said, "Do you know where to get a pony and cart, I want to go to market?"â€”I said I knew several, and I got a pony and cart at Mr. Greenfield'sâ€”I drove it round to the side gate of the shopâ€”I got there after four o'clockâ€”the prisoner opened the gate, and said, "Go into the shop"â€”I went inâ€”the cart was at the gate for about ten minutes, and then the prisoner drove past the shop about 4.30 with the cart loaded with something all covered overâ€”he came back about 8 p.m.â€”there was nothing in the cart except a planeâ€”I said to himâ€”"You have left something in it"â€”he said, "Never mind, I shall want the cart again tomorrow"â€”I then took the cart to Greenfield'sâ€”on the 8th the prisoner wanted a vanâ€”I went to Greenfield's, but the van was not inâ€”I had to go back to the prisoner to see if the cart would doâ€”he said he should have to make shift with itâ€”I went back and got the cart for him, that was between 10 and 11 a.m.â€”I took it to the side doorâ€”he ordered me into the shop again, and about eleven I saw the prisoner go away with the cartâ€”there was something in it covered over with something darkâ€”he had said that he wanted the cart to take things to marketâ€”the prisoner came back with it about fourâ€”it was quite emptyâ€”I took it back to the yardâ€”the prisoner told me he would want a van in the morning, which I got for himâ€”I took it to the side gateâ€”before I went to get it the prisoner said, "If you see a respectable young follow I can do with him, but don't bring a rough fellow"â€”I brought a young fellowâ€”he and the prisoner brought some furniture and a bath out of the houseâ€”I was in the van, and I could not pack it quick enough for himâ€”there were no boxes or trunksâ€”the bath had some
thing like crockery in it, but it was covered over with something darkâ€”

the two of them lifted it up to the vanâ€”I think it was heavyâ€”when the van was loaded the prisoner told me to send the young fellow into the shop, and then he said, "If you drive through here you will come to Newington Causeway railway arches, I will be there as quick as you"â€”I drove there and the prisoner came in about ten minutesâ€”I was waiting for him, and he said, "You had better get up again and follow me"â€”he walked on the pavement, but because of the traffic I could not get through as quick as he couldâ€”he kept twenty or thirty yards in front of meâ€”we got to London Bridgeâ€”he said, "Go down Fenchurch Street, down on the left, not too far down"â€”I was going to pull up in Fenchurch Street, and the prisoner said "A little further"â€”I got to Aldgate Churchâ€”there was a lot of trafficâ€”I was about fifteen minutes pulling throughâ€”he pulled me up, and said "Get down, you have got some money, and get back to the shop as quick as you can, take the 'bus at Cornhill to Camberwell"â€”he drove the van straight offâ€”I went back to the shop, and about 7 p.m. I got a telegram, "Jim, come at once, Harry, Whitechapel Church"â€”I went off at onceâ€”I waited about fifteen minutes at the churchâ€”when I saw the prisoner, he said, "You have arrived, you have done it quick enough; did not you give orders at the place where you got the van that I wanted it for the day; I have had no light, and have had to put it up for the day at some livery stables because I have not got a lamp"â€”I said, "Get a Chinese lantern"â€”I went into the stables and got a lamp and drove homeâ€”the prisoner said he had to meet a gentleman at Aldgateâ€”I took the van to Greenfield'sâ€”there was nothing in itâ€”I got to Greenfield's just after eightâ€”next morning, the 10th, the prisoner came round just after nine, and said, "If anyone calls I shall be home at eleven o'clock, and if any travellers come don't take their lists in without they leave their price list"â€”he never came backâ€”I did not know where he had gone or where to find himâ€”I did not know anything of a house being taken by him at Leytonâ€”on the 10th the brokers came in for rent, and I and my wife left the premises on the 11thâ€”on the 6th, by the prisoner's orders, I had pawned some booksâ€”he had said that Mr. Darby had lent him a few things as he had run short of cash, and said, "I want you to take this box up to the pawnbroker's and hand it to the pawnbrokerâ€”I did soâ€”I did not give any nameâ€”I got a ticketâ€”I got 3s. on the boxâ€”I do not know the pawnbroker's nameâ€”the shop was at the corner of Albany Roadâ€”I gave the ticket and the money to the prisonerâ€”I tried to pawn another lot of books that day, but the pawnbroker would not take them inâ€”I took them back to the prisoner, and he sent me to take the orders for the groceries and teas and baconâ€”when I came back from that the prisoner gave me a small parcel, tied up and sealed, and said, "Take this to a pawnbroker's in Walworth Road"â€”I took it down, and it was opened by the pawnbrokerâ€”there were two rings in itâ€”the pawn-broker said, "Tell your governor they are metal"â€”I got 22s. on them, which I gave to the prisoner with the ticketâ€”that is the gentleman I pawned them with (Mr. Tilly).

Cross-examined. Wyndham Road is about fifteen or twenty minutes walk from my houseâ€”the prisoner-said he wanted the umbrella pawned because he was short of cash until 10 o'clock, when the bank openedâ€”

he told me the Darbys still had their furniture in the house, but he had taken the shopâ€”I helped him to take away the furniture because I was in his service, and acted as his servant, he did not say the furniture belonged to the Darbys, he said, "The Darbys' things have not gone away yet, so don't interfere or go upstairs"â€”we could have gone upstairs if we wanted to, but we obeyed his ordersâ€”I did not go upstairs till I went up with the brokersâ€”I did not go up and help bring down a bedstead or bring a key from my home to take the bedstead down withâ€”I have got a key for a bedstead at homeâ€”I did not know why he told me to drive to different streets with the furnitureâ€”I did not notice anything in the prisoner's manner that was timid or fearful, he spoke quite openly about the Darbysâ€”one morning he said. "If you had not gone so early last night, Mr. Darby came just as you had gone home"â€”the prisoner was not restless when he was indoors, he was in the parlour writing and reading, he was only home for the evening timeâ€”he came into the shop about twiceâ€”he never served a customer to my knowledgeâ€”I was there all the time except when he sent me on errandsâ€”he was away a good dealâ€”I did a good deal of pawning by his instructionsâ€”I did not ask him any questions about thatâ€”I was quite willing to do anything I was told.
Re-examined. When I went upstairs with the broker's men, all the doors were open bar the centre one which the broker's men busted in.

JOHN HOLMES . I live at 12, Scarsdale Road, Albany Road, Camber-wellâ€”on November 29th. I was employed at 2, Portland Street, Walworthâ€”I saw Goodwin, and sold him a sash weight similar to this one.
Cross-examined. I am a plumber's foremanâ€”this was the only weight I Lad on the premisesâ€”it is very exceptional for us to have one at all.
THOMAS DYSON (Police Sergeant L.) On January 19th, I visited 22, Wyndham Road, and made an inventoryâ€”I found Exhibit 27 there in the back parlour.

HARRY DARBY . My brother, William John Darby, had a business at 22, Wyndham Roadâ€”I am acquainted with his writingâ€”this paper (Exhibit 27) looks like an imitation of his writing, but I should not think it is hisâ€”Read, "22, Wyndham Road, Camberwell, S.E., December 1st, 1902, Received of Mr. William Thomas Louden the sum of thirty pounds (Â£30), as a deposit, and in part payment of the sum of fifty pounds (Â£50). for the purchase of the grocery and general business carried on at 22, Wyndham Road, Camberwel), S.E., with all the goodwill, fixtures, fittings, utensils, and stock in trade of the same. This deposit is made subject to landlord's approval of the purchaser as tenant."

CHARLES FREDERICK NEWBY . I am a baker, of 46, Harris Street, Camber-wellâ€”I was in the habit of serving the Darbys at 22, Wyndham Roadâ€”I last served them with bread on December 1st, at 8.20 a.m.â€”I saw Mr.â€”Darbyâ€”I called later in the day and sow Mrs. Goodwin.

ANN WHITTINGTON . I live at 20, Wyndham Road, which is next door to 22, which is a corner houseâ€”I was in the habit of dealing with Mr. Darbyâ€”I have a sister whose birthday is on December 1st. and on that day I remember going to Mr. Darby's shop about 11 a.m.â€”I had a conver
sation
with himâ€”I called again at 1 o'clock, and found the door shutâ€”I called again at 5 o'clock, and saw Mr. Goodwin and his wife.
Cross-examined. The Darbys had been there, I think, seven months and a fortnightâ€”I knew them quite well, but not before they came there.

MAURICE SOLOMON . I am a pawnbroker of 91. Camberwell Road, which is the comer of Albany Roadâ€”on December 1st, I took into pledge a gold watch and chain and a mounted coin, this (Produced) is the contract note relating to them, and this (Produced.) is the watch and chainâ€”I advanced Â£7 on themâ€”I gave this counterfoil to the person who pawned themâ€”I cannot recognise the personâ€”the counterfoil was signed W. T. Louden, by the person who pledged the articles in my presenceâ€”it was about 12 o'clockâ€”on December 6th. I took a parcel-of books into pledge from James Goodwin, this (Produced) is the ticket relating to themâ€”I advanced 15s. on them, they were pledged in the name of Charles Darbyâ€”I handed the ticket to Goodwin.

ALICE ELIZABETH BALDWIN . I am the wife of Frederick Baldwin, and live at Catfordâ€”my sister Beatrice was married to William John Darby, who was a grocer at 22, Wyndham Road, Camberwellâ€”I last saw them alive about the middle of Novemberâ€”they had only one child, a girl, born on September 28thâ€”they lived quite alone in the houseâ€”on November 29th I received a letter from my sisterâ€”I wrote her a reply by return of postâ€”I did not get any reply to itâ€”on December 3rd, I went to 22, Wynd
ham Road, I got there about 6.45 p.m.â€”I went into the shop, I saw Mr. and Mrs. Goodwin; they said the man who had bought the shop was coming, and I said I would wait as I could not understand itâ€”the prisoner came inâ€”I talked to him for nearly an hourâ€”I said I could not understand the shop being sold so quickly, but I knew that my brother-in-law was going to sell the businessâ€”he said, "Oh, I first negotiated with Mr. Darby on Saturday morning; I was so satisfied with the business, I have paid Â£30 on deposit, and if Mr. Darby comes in I will settle with him then"â€”I waited some long time, the prisoner said he was expected every moment and asked me to have a chairâ€”I said, "No, thank you," and after a time, I said, "I cannot wait any longer"â€”he said, he could not understand why Mr. Darby had not been inâ€”I said I had come in answer to my sister's letterâ€”he said, "Oh, yes, they had a little baby, had not they?" and that he thought that Mrs. Darby was a very nice Ladyâ€”I said, "Where have they gone, did not they leave any address?"â€”he said, "They did not leave any address, they were simply going to friends"â€”I left the house about 8.30 or 8.45â€”on December 29th, in consequence of a police telegramâ€”I went to 89, Church Road, Leytonâ€”I went all over the houseâ€”all theâ€”furniture and wearing apparel and movables that I saw there. I recog
nised as having belonged to my sister and her husbandâ€”this brown over-coat (Produced) I recognise as my brother-in-law's, and these two gold rings (Produced) as my sister'sâ€”I went through the articles on this list with the police, and recognised them as belonging to Mr. and Mrs. Darbyâ€”at 89, Church Road, I went through this list, and with the exception of a few articles, which I have marked with an asterisk, I recognise every
thing as belonging to my sisterâ€”on December 31st I went to the

mortuary at Leyton, where I was shown three bodies, which I recognised as my brother-in-law's, my sister's, and her child'sâ€”at Camberwell Police Station, I saw a book case which I recognised belonging to the Darbys.

Cross-examined. The prisoner came in about half or three-quarters of an hour after I got to the shopâ€”he did not shake hands with meâ€”he flushed when I said I was Mrs. Baldwin, and had come to see my sisterâ€”beyond that he did not seem to be anxious to get me to goâ€”he was not with me all the time that I was thereâ€”he was in and out of the shop parlourâ€”he did not offer to take me upstairsâ€”I asked him if they had taken the furnitureâ€”he said, "No, it is locked up upstairs"â€”he said that Mr. Darby had been there the night beforeâ€”when I left I did not make arrangements to come back again, because I thought they had gone to my father's or to Mr. Darby'sâ€”the prisoner said he was certainly going to see Mr. Darby at the end of the week to settle up the matter of the moneyâ€”he did not say where he was going to see himâ€”when I left the house I had no suspicion that this terrible thing had happenedâ€”I did not know why the prisoner flushed when I spoke to him, it might have been from walking, or a lot of thingsâ€”when he was talking to me he was pleasant and affableâ€”I did not notice any fear in his manner.
GEORGE ENDEAN (43 K.) Produced and proved a plan of 22, Wyndham Road, and plans of the first and upper floors.

ARTHUR PEARSON LUFF . F.R.C.P. I am lecturer at St. Mary's Hospitalâ€”on January 4th, with Inspector McCarthy, I visited 22, Wyndham Road and examined some stains there on the floor, walls, and window upstairsâ€”on the right of the fireplace in the front room, upstairs, there were several blood stains which had been projected from a living artery or arteries, and facing towards the fireplace, they had been projected from left to rightâ€”they were entirely on the right side of the fireplace and there were also several underneath the mantelshelf, but none on the top of itâ€”having regard to the stains on the mantelshelf, the person was probably sitting on the left side of the fireplace, facing the windowâ€”there were several bloodstains at two different levels on the wall between the fireplace and the window, which also had all been projected from an artery or arteries during lifeâ€”those on the lower level were simply a continuation of the spurts or stains on the fireplace, those on the higher level must have been caused while the person was standing upâ€”on the window sash, and on the lower part of the window blind, there were bloodstains, and there were a few bloodstains on one of the lowest panes of the window, and the lowest part of the blindâ€”there were two very large stains on the floor one in front of the fireplace, and the other in front of the left windowâ€”outside the door at the head of the staircase there is a small landing with three doors opening from itâ€”on the outer side of the door of the front room there were several blood stains which had been projected from arteries or an artery, during lifeâ€”on the outer side of the door of the bedroom facing the front door, there were also some blood stains, which had been projected from an artery or arteries during life, and which had been slightly washedâ€”the stains on the front-room door came on it when it was closed or partly closed, but in all probability closedâ€”on the floor of the back

bedroom there were two large stains, more or less covered over by means of inkâ€”I removed some of the panals of the doors of both rooms and a pane of glassâ€”I examined them by the chemical and microscopical tests, they all contained evidence of having on them mammalian blood, which had been shed from four to six or eight weeksâ€”the first article was examined on January 5th, and the last on January 19thâ€”I saw two sash-weightsâ€”No. 5 was the one which was usedâ€”I was informed that it was brought from 22, Wyndham Roadâ€”on the hanging end, I found a quantity of a dark red stain which I found to consist of mammalian blood, which on January 5th was from four to six weeks old, and sticking to it by one end was a single hair which I have now with meâ€”I requested the police to bring me samples of the hair from the heads of William John and Beatrice Darbyâ€”I compared those with the single hair on the sash-weight, and found that it was exactly similar to the hair of William John Darbyâ€”on January 6th, I received this saw (Produced) from Detective Sergeant Milton, it was found at Wyndham Roadâ€”I examined it on the 9th, and found a few stains of mammalian blood upon itâ€”I received a scarf which I was informed was found in the back bedroom at Wyndham Road, and a shoe which was found in a cupboard in the front roomâ€”the scarf was simply saturated with mammalian blood, from five to seven weeks old, and on the inner side of the heel of the shoe there was one blood stain, also from five to seven weeks oldâ€”on January 4th, I went to Carter Street Police Station, and was shown a book case or wardrobe, on the right edge of which and about 15 inches from the top I saw some hair sticking in a dark clotâ€”I removed it, the clot consisted of mammalian blood four to six weeks old, and the hair was identical with William John Darby'sâ€”I also saw the top of a round table that had some stains on itâ€”I had two pieces of the table sawn away, the stains were blood stainsâ€”on January 4th, a hair net was given to me by the police at 22, Wyndham Road, in the front roomâ€”there was some hair and a comb with it, I compared them with samples given me, and it was similar to that of Beatrice Darby's.

Cross-examined. I should imagine that the attack on these unfortunate people was a very ferocious oneâ€”I have given evidence in a large number of legal casesâ€”we group the predisposing causes of insanity into mental and moral onesâ€”heredity and stress may be predisposing causes, but I do not think you can bring them all into two groupsâ€”there are very many types of insanityâ€”if on the maternal side of a family you can trace insanity for some time past, that might be a predisposing cause to insanity in an individual, but I should require to know the extent of it if I was reporting to an Asylumâ€”if it began with the prisoner's grandfather's sister, and was traced to the brother of the prisoner's mother, and then to two or three of the prisoner's nieces, that would be a close connection of insanity in the familyâ€”if I had to report on a case like that, I should report that those were possibly predisposing causesâ€”if it was undoubted insanity, and radiated to nieces and sisters in a collateral way, it would be stronger than missing a generationâ€”if there is a depression at the back of the prisoner's head which was the result of an accident some years ago, it might come under the head of stress, butâ€”I cannot say without examining itâ€”

if there was a depressed fracture of the skull, that might be so; assuming that to be so, the thickening of the bone might lead to atrophy of brainâ€”pressure of the brain might possibly lead to insanity, which you might discover by symptoms, or the X Raysâ€”I do not think you could discover it by touch or feelingâ€”insanity sometimes skips a generationâ€”I know the facts of this case; from my experience, I should not say that many of the acts in it are those of a person of unsound mindâ€”I do not know that I should consider the weapon with which the murder was committed is a very extraordinary oneâ€”it is a very effective oneâ€”I should think a weapon of this kind is a very easy thing to obtain, as they are to be found in every houseâ€”I cannot say that I have ever heard of a sash-weight having been used before for such a crimeâ€”looking at the case from an ordinary point of view, one would say that to commit these wholesale murders would be scarcely worth the whileâ€”I should not say that the doing of it is an indi
cation of insanityâ€”I have been connected with similar cases, where over-anxiety about detection has not been noticed in persons who were described as sane, and who were never found to be to the contrary; in those cases insanity was set up as a defence, but two of them were not successfulâ€”a sane person is not always over anxious, it depends on temperament, many people are callous without being insaneâ€”I do not think it is an indication of insanity to commit wholesale murder, there is no reason why a man who does so should not be insane, but I should like to know the facts of the case before I decidedâ€”it is decidedly exceptional to meet with a case of wholesale murderâ€”I can recollect a case in which there were two murders committed, but never three in my personal experienceâ€”it is very common in cases of insanity, for an insane person to be controlled and influenced by the same motives which actuate persons who are sane, but 99 per cent of the cases of insanity are not insane altogether, they have got many sane sidesâ€”violent impulses to acts of murder or homicidal attacks may be dormant in an individual for a long time without showing outside expressionâ€”a person may not show to the outside world evidence of the conflict going on inside his mind, and there may not be any such conflictâ€”those people may have uncontrollable destructive impulses, but whether the person knows' the difference between right and wrong at the time is the debatable pointâ€”there are some eminent medical men who hold that insane persons may commit an act knowing it to be wrong, but are unable to control the impulse to commit itâ€”there are some cases in which the act itself is the chief evidence of mental disorder in the individualâ€”in the majority of eases of homicidal mania, the person who commits the act does not seek to obliterate all traces of the crime, they are quite indifferent to the tracesâ€”my experience of criminals is that indifference as to concealing the act is a characteristic of insanityâ€”I should say that in the majority of undoubted cases of insanity persons are indifferent as to obliterating traces of the crime when acts of this sort are committedâ€”persons do not always show great calmness, but they do show absence of fear; they sometimes show great cunning and ingenuity, but at the same time they may be quite indifferent in effecting concealment and indifferent to the number of lives they takeâ€”I do not say that that is evidence of insanity,

but it is a frequent consequence; it is more likely to be associated with an unsound mind than with a sound oneâ€”I should say it is probably the case that an insane person committing a murder would not have accomplices, however colossal the scheme may beâ€”an insane person suffering from a homicidal paroxysm might kill any number of persons, but so might a sane personâ€”I do not say he would do so without a motiveâ€”I cannot say what is sufficient motiveâ€”a sane person committing an act which might forfeit his life, might not have a sufficient motiveâ€”I have known a few pounds be sufficient motive, and where there was no evidence of insanity; both the cases I was thinking of were murders done in trains, I believe both on the Brighton line: the murderer might not know the amount of money the victim had, but a person probably would not be carrying much moneyâ€”I believe one was in a first class carriage.

Re-examined. Homicidal uncontrollable impulses are generally suddenâ€”a person who is subject to them would not lay his plans some time before-handâ€”the plans would of course be just as suddenly arranged as the actâ€”I have not examined the prisoner or his family history.

JAMES KNIGHT . I am an ironmonger of 168, Camberwell Road, and landlord of 22, Wyndham Roadâ€”John Darby was my tenant of those premisesâ€”I last saw him on Saturday, November 29th, about 10 p.m.â€”he made an appointment to meet me on Monday evening at my shopâ€”he did not come, and I went down to Wyndham Road for his rentâ€”I saw the prisoner, and told him I had called for the rentâ€”he said he was the purchaser of the shop, and that he had paid a deposit for the premisesâ€”I asked for Mr. Darbyâ€”he said that he was not thereâ€”I said, "I had an appointment with Mr. Darby for Monday evening between 6 and 7"â€”he said that he could not understand why it was not kept, as he himself had made an appointment with Mr. Darby, and he had not kept itâ€”I went there from day to day, and on occasions I was there twice a dayâ€”on December 3rd, I went there and told the prisoner he could not become my tenant, and that he had no right to pay the Â£30 deposit, and that I should not take him unless I saw Mr. Darbyâ€”to the best of my belief he said that he had seen Mr. Darby at 10 o'clock on Thursday nightâ€”I asked him why he had not brought him round to see meâ€”he said, "Because it was too late"â€”I had previously told him if Mr. Darby called, he was to bring him round no matter what time it wasâ€”I put the matter into my broker's hands, and on the 10th made a distraint for rentâ€”after the furni
ture was seized I locked the house up.

Cross-examined. The prisoner was always ready to see me when I calledâ€”I saw no reason not to accept him, except that he was not intro
duced by Mr. Darby; if Mr. Darby had been round to see me, I had no reason why I should not accept himâ€”Darby was perfectly well known in the neighbourhood, but he had only been there six or seven monthsâ€”the debt due to me was Â£2 18s. 4d.â€”I do not know the amount of the property taken away, Mr. Wyatt, the bailiff, must account for that; he cleared away everything there was there, with the exception of a few oddmentsâ€”a sash-weight was found there afterwardsâ€”I do not know if it was there when we wereâ€”I believe it was found on the mantelpieceâ€”
I did not notice that the prisoner was annoyedâ€”I noticed nothing against him at all.

CHARLES WYATT . I am an estate agent of 247, Camberwell Roadâ€”on December 10th, I received instructions from Mr. Knight to distrain for rent at 22, Wyndham Roadâ€”I went there that day, and left a man in possessionâ€”I went there next day, and went up stairsâ€”the door of the front room was lockedâ€”I forced it, and found a bookcase there, and a tableâ€”I took possession of themâ€”I have since seen them at Carter Street Police Stationâ€”I saw a sash weight there.

ARTHUR FRANCIS BALLS . I am a clerk to Messrs. Bassett, house agents, of Lea Bridge Roadâ€”they had instructions to let 89, Church Road, Leyton, and on December 3rd, at 10.30 a.m. the prisoner calledâ€”he gave the name of Edgar Edwards, 5, Barnsbury Road, Islingtonâ€”we asked for refer
ences, he gave themâ€”we wrote to the persons whose names he gave, and received back these two letters (One from 22, Wyndham Road, dated December 3rd, and signed Wm. Darby., stated that Mr. Edwards had been a tenant of his for nearly two years, and the other signed G. Barton, 230, Graham Road, Hackney, stated that he had known Mr. Edwards 3 1/2 years)â€”the whole of those two letters is type written, including the signaturesâ€”the prisoner called again on December 5thâ€”I told him he could have the house and gave him a note to Mr. Childsâ€”he said that he should like to get in by Saturday, December 6th.

JANE BERESFORD . I am the wife of Samuel Beresfordâ€”we keep a news-agent's shop at 230, Graham Road, Hackneyâ€”we have lived there about five yearsâ€”I do not know anybody named Barton thereâ€”we take in lettersâ€”I do not remember any letters coming there in that name.

FREDERICK DUNCAN . I keep a news agent's shop at 5, Barnsbury Roadâ€”I take in letters addressed to strangers thereâ€”I remember two letters coming addressed to Edgar Edwardsâ€”nobody called for themâ€”I gave them to the police.

THOMAS CHILDS . I live at 77, Church Road, Leyton, and at the beginning of December I had the keys of No. 89â€”I remember the prisoner coming with an order to look at the houseâ€”I afterwards saw him there again, he had a small butcher's cart with himâ€”I cannot fix the dates.

SARAH SUMMERS . I live at 22, Grafton Terrace, Hampsteadâ€”I have known the prisoner for years by the name of Owenâ€”I have a son by him aged fourteen yearsâ€”on November 26th the prisoner came to see meâ€”I had not seen him for nearly five yearsâ€”he did not tell me where he was living on the first dayâ€”I saw him again on the 27th and 28th he told me he had taken a shop and bought some furniture for it, and on the 28th he told me he wanted me to come and look after itâ€”he said he was going to open it on Saturday the 29th, that the rooms were upstairs, but there was one room we should not be able to go into for some timeâ€”he made an appoint
ment for me to go to the shop, but he sent a telegram saying he could not goâ€”on December 10th, in consequence of a telegram that he sent me, I met him at Broad Street Station, I think about 8 p.m.â€”he told me he was going to show me the house he had takenâ€”he had written me a letter saying he had taken a house in the countryâ€”we went to 89, Church

Road, Leyton, we stayed there that nightâ€”next day I saw Jones thereâ€”I looked over the house I went into the front and back bedroomsâ€”I did not go into the room on the stairsâ€”I opened the door in the evening when it was dark, but I did no go inside, the prisoner was there when I opened the doorâ€”I do not think he said anything, because I do not think he knew I wentâ€”when I went into the back room, he said, "Come out, there is nothing there for you to see"â€”I saw a box there, I left the shop with Jones and the prisonerâ€”I parted from the prisoner at Broad Streetâ€”nothing was arranged about meeting again, and I never saw the prisoner againâ€”he said he was going to finish furnishing the house, and as soon as that was done, I was to go there.
Re-examined. I have known the prisoner more than fifteen yearsâ€”the longest period that I have seen him daily, or nearly daily, is, I think, three or four months.
Cross-examined. I know all the prisoner's peopleâ€”there was only one room in the house that I was not allowed to go into.
ALBERT HENRY ABBOTT . I am foreman to Mr. Greenfield, of 19, Waterloo Street, Camberwellâ€”he lets out vans and traps for hireâ€”on December 5th, we let out a pony and cart to James Goodwin.

GEORGE SUSHAM .â€”I am twelve years old, and live at 59, Crown Street, Camberwell, with my parentsâ€”one side of our house faces 22, Wyndham Roadâ€”one evening, I think it was December 8th, when I came home from school, I saw a pony and trap at the side gate of the houseâ€”I come home from school at 4.30 and have tea as soon as I get inâ€”I saw the cart before I had teaâ€”I saw the hunchback man Goodwin and the prisoner thereâ€”I saw two sacks put separately on the trapâ€”I could not see what was in them, the prisoner carried them out, they looked heavy.

Cross-examined. Goodwin was there all the time that I was watchingâ€”I was not there when any furniture was brought outâ€”I am quite sure the prisoner was there, he had a velvet collar to his overcoatâ€”I did not see his faceâ€”I was standing almost next to Goodwin.

CHARLES SHEPHERD . I went with Goodwin to 22, Wyndham Road, to help load a vanâ€”I do not remember the dateâ€”I went into the back roomâ€”Goodwin was outside all the timeâ€”only furniture was put into the van while I was there.

AGNES HICKMAN , I live at 101, Ampthill Road, Bow, and am employed at the post office in Whitechapel Roadâ€”this telegram was handed to me at 5.15 p.m. on December 9thâ€”I do not remember who it was who handed it to me.

WILLIAM JONES . I live at the Working Man's Home, Commercial Streetâ€”I have known the prisoner for fifteen yearsâ€”on December 9th I met him at the corner of Osborn Streetâ€”I saw him go into the post office, and followed him thereâ€”I saw him write a telegram and hand it over the counterâ€”he told me to stop a minute or two and he would speak to meâ€”he then told me he had sent a telegram to tell somebody to come and fetch the van home, as he said a policeman or somebody had stopped him and wanted to know where his light was, and that he had put the van up at some stables somewhere handy, but did not say whereâ€”he asked

me how long it would take for people to come over from Camberwel.'â€”I told him about a couple of hoursâ€”we then went and had drinks together to pass the time until he thought the people would have come for the vanâ€”he said, "I will give you 1s. to get me a sash weight in the morning"â€”at the last house we had a drink at he said, "They have turned up it is all right, they have taken the van on"â€”we then went to the doctor's in Leman Street and got the prisoner's hand dressed, and arranged to meet next day at Bethnal Green Junctionâ€”he gave me 1s. to get the sash weight, which I gotâ€”it was like this 5 lbs. oneâ€”I met him next morning at 10.45 a.m. at Bethnal Green Junctionâ€”we got into the train and went to Stratford, and then walked to Leytonâ€”he said he wanted me to clean some windowsâ€”we went to 89. Church Roadâ€”I put the sash weight down on the cupboardâ€”while cleaning the windows I did not notice that any of them had a sash weight missingâ€”I saw a man digging in the gardenâ€”when I was going away in the evening the prisoner gave me this brown overcoat (Produced), and said "Put that on" (Identified as Darby's)â€”when we got to the station, and when he was booking to Liverpool Street, he gave me 1s. 6d.â€”before we went to the station he gave me a suit of clothes to pawnâ€”he tied them up himselfâ€”I pawned them with William Sutton at 344, High Street, and got this ticket from him dated December 10thâ€”I gave the money to the prisoner and he asked me for the ticketâ€”I handed it to himâ€”he said, "You may as well keep that"â€”I gave it to the policeâ€”we went to Liverpool Street togetherâ€”next day I went down to Leyton again to finish the window cleaning and clean the bath and water closet.â€”I saw Summers there that day.
Cross-examined. On the second day I did not see anybody there except Summers and the prisonerâ€”on the first day I saw someone else, but not upstairs.

ELIZABETH RAWLINGS . I am the wife of Joseph James Rawlings, and live at 79, Church Road. Leytonâ€”on Friday, December 3rd, the prisoner came to my door and asked if Mr. Rawlings was inâ€”I said yes, and sent my husband to the doorâ€”I saw a pony and trap thereâ€”my husband after
wards did some digging for the prisonerâ€”I saw the prisoner with a trap also on the 8th and 9th.

JOSEPH JAMES RAWLINGS . I am a labourer of 79, Church Road. Leyton; the prisoner and Childs came to my house and asked me to do some digging in the garden at 89, Church Roadâ€”the prisoner asked me to do the garden plainly all overâ€”I did so from bottom to topâ€”I worked there on Saturday Monday, and Tuesdayâ€”on Tuesday, about 12 a.m., some goods arrived in a little pony cart; there were about half a dozen boxes with old books and one box with old clothes in itâ€”I helped to carry them inâ€”one of the boxes was very heavyâ€”it was a basket boxâ€”I could not see what was in itâ€”the prisoner did not say what was in themâ€”he came with the next lot in a little pony and vanâ€”there were two wooden boxes and a big tin trunkâ€”I carried them upstairsâ€”I said. "That one is very heavy"â€”I meant the tin trunk; he said, "Oh, that is only valuable crockery."
SOPHIA FREER . I am the wife of James Freer, of 91, Church Road, Leyton, which is next door to 89â€”I remember some furniture arriving

at 89â€”I saw Mr. Rawlings helping to unload itâ€”I cannot fix the dateâ€”about the following week I was at my bedroom window at the back of the houseâ€”I saw the prisoner digging a hole in his garden; it was a round hole; he was standing in itâ€”I could only see his head from the windowâ€”next time I looked out, which I think was the next day or the day after that, the hole was closed up.
Cross-examined. The prisoner was digging the hole in the morningâ€”I did not know he was our next door neighbour till he came and told me so.

WILLIAM SILBY . I am assistant to Messrs Grisnett and Walker, pawn-brokers, of 2, Merrow Street, Walworth Roadâ€”on December 6th, two gold rings were pledged with us by Goodwinâ€”this is the ticket I issued in respect to that pledgeâ€”the rings were pledged in the name of W. J. Darby, 22, Wyndham Roadâ€”I produce the rings.

HARRY ELLIOTT . I am assistant to Mr. William Sutton, pawnbroker, of. 344, High Road, Leyton,â€”on December 10th a suit of clothes was given to me by a man giving the name of Jones; this is the ticket I issuedâ€”I have identified Jonesâ€”on December 20th I took in a clock and ornament; this is the ticketâ€”the prisoner pledged those articles.

HARRY DARBY (Re-examined.) I identify this watch and these books produced by Solomon as my brother's, also the suit of clothes and the clock and ornament produced by Elliot as belonging to my brotherâ€”these are some letters which were written to me by my brother.

THOMAS HENRY GURRIN . I am an expert in handwriting, and have had many years' experienceâ€”these exhibits, 8 and 9, which are proved by Goodwin to have been written in his presence by the prisoner, I have compared with this contract note as to a gold watch and chain signed "W. T., Louden"â€”in my opinion that signature is in the same writing as exhibits 8 and 9.

WILLIAM HATCHER . I am a business transfer agent of lavender Hillâ€”on December 3rd the prisoner called on me; he gave the name of William Darby of 22, Wyndham Road, Camberwellâ€”he wanted to buy a stationery and tobacconist's businessâ€”I gave him several addressesâ€”I received this post card from him on December 8th.

WALTER YOUNG (Inspector J.) On December 23rd I was at Leyton police-station when the prisoner was searchedâ€”on him I found a pawn-ticketâ€”the same evening I went to 89, Church Road, with Sergeant Melville, where I found some more pawn tickets in a case bearing the name of Darbyâ€”on my return to the prisoner I said, "Are you Darby?"â€”he replied,. "No, that is a friend I am buying the business for. "Meaning Garland's businessâ€”he was then in custody on a charge of maliciously wounding John Garland.

GEORGE MELVILLE (Detective Sergeant J.) On December 23rd. in the evening, I went to 89, Church Roadâ€”in the upstairs room I found a number of cards bearing the name of Darby, also some pawn ticketsâ€”on December 29th I went there with Mrs. Baldwin and showed her the clothing and furniture, which she identifiedâ€”on December 30th I went to 22, Wyndham Road, and searched the premisesâ€”I found a sash weight on the mantelpiece in the back roomâ€”there was a quantity of what appeared

to be blood and hair on one endâ€”I handed it to Dr. Luff in the same condi
tion that I found itâ€”I found some blood stains in the front and back roomâ€”the house was locked upâ€”Mr. Knight let me inâ€”on January 8th I found three keys in a dressing-table drawer in the front room at 89, Church Road, and on January 10th I took them to 22, Wyndham Roadâ€”I found they fitted the door leading from the front to the back parlours and also the door leading to the stairs, and another key fitted the front bedroom door.
Cross-examined. When I found the sash weight the blood was slightly more damp than it is nowâ€”it had not been washed.

THOMAS HUGHES (87 J.) On December 30th, acting on instructions, I examined the back garden at 89, Church Road, Leytonâ€”I found a soft place thereâ€”I dug down about 4 ft. 6 in. when I found six sacks and a bundleâ€”I sent for Dr. Jekyllâ€”he examined the sacks and their contents.

LEWIS NUGENT JEKYLL . I live at Kingsbury House, Leytonstone, and am divisional police surgeon for the districtâ€”on December 30th I was called to 89, Church Road, where I saw six sacks containing the dismem
bered bodies of a man and woman, the heads and limbs had been cut off, I also saw the body of a child, which was intact, the heads were quite recog
nisable, the cause of death was due to injury to the heads in the cases of the man and woman, and in the case of the child to strangulation, there was a handkerchief tied tightly round its neckâ€”there were extensive frac
tures to the skulls of the man and womanâ€”there had been three or four blows deliveredâ€”the face of the woman had been smashed in, and there had also been a blow on the back of each of their headsâ€”the serious blows had been struck from the frontâ€”the blows on the back of the heads were not of a serious nature, they might have been done in fallingâ€”the bodies had been dismembered by means of a saw.

Cross-examined. I should say that in each of the two cases the cause of death was from a blow which had been delivered from the frontâ€”I cannot say if it was the first blow or notâ€”the blows were undoubtedly tremendous and ferocious.

JOHN MCCARTHY (Inspector L.) On December 30th I visited 22, Wynd
ham. Roadâ€”among other things I found there a hair-net and a comb lying on the floorâ€”I handed them to Dr. Luffâ€”I noticed the ceiling of the shop, blood had oozed through from the floor aboveâ€”I took to Dr. Luff parts of the wall paper, the floor, and the door panelsâ€”I also showed him a bookcase.

HERBERT MILTON (Inspector L.) On January 30th I visited 22, Wyndham Roadâ€”I found a silk scarf in a grate in the back bedroomâ€”I found an empty ink-bottle in the back room, ink stains on the floor and blood stains underneath the inkâ€”I found two saws covered up in the shop with news
paper, also a lady's shoe, which was shown to Dr. Luff.
Cross-examined. The other shoe was found at Leyton.
GEORGE FRIEND (Detective) I found a lady's shoe in a bag in the hole in the garden, at 89, Church Road, with some more clothing.
HENRY COLLINS (Inspector) On December 31st I was present when the prisoner was identified by Mrs. Baldwinâ€”I then said to the prisoner.

"Now, Edgar Edwards, otherwise Louden, you will be charged with the wilful murder of William John Darby, Beatrice Darby, and Ethel Beatrice, their child, on or about November 29th, supposed to be at 22, Wyndham Road, Camberwell"â€”he said, "My dear Sir, I know nothing about it"â€”he was then charged and said, "Good goodness"â€”he was taken before the Court and the charge was read over by the Chairman of the Benchâ€”in reply the prisoner said, "Surely, Sir, there is some great mistake"â€”he was then remanded on the charge on which he was in custody.
JOHN GARLAND (Not examined in chief).

Cross-examined. The assault on me took place on December 23rdâ€”I was at the prisoner's house at Leyton to discuss some business matters with himâ€”I was with him several hoursâ€”he paced about a great deal and apologised for keeping me waitingâ€”there was nothing in his manner to cause me to fear him in the slightestâ€”his attack was absolutely unprovoked, and took place in a momentâ€”he gave me a very severe blow, it almost knocked the senses out of me, and it was followed by a number of blows rained upon me while I was on the groundâ€”in another moment he might have killed meâ€”towards the end of the attack he tried to force a handker
chief or cloth into my mouthâ€”he was almost exhausted by the force of his own blowsâ€”he began to show signs of fatigueâ€”I had a hat on at firstâ€”I cannot say when I lost itâ€”I was taken away from the houseâ€”I think the prisoner might have attacked me at any other time while I was in the houseâ€”we were on perfectly good termsâ€”I found him a pleasant manâ€”I did not know what became of him after the attack.
By MR. MUIR. While I was in" the house the prisoner said he was expecting a man who he had left at Clapton to do about an hour's work: he never arrived.
By the COURT. He had been discussing buying a business from meâ€”he asked me if I had anyone at home, and I told him no.

JOSEPH WILLIAM DUFFIELD . I live at 1, Palace Gate Mansions, and am a plumber and decoratorâ€”according to the prisoner's statement I am the prisoner's uncle, but I have not seen him for thirty or forty years, when he was ten or twelve years oldâ€”if he is the man he says he is I married his mother's sisterâ€”if he is the man he says he is his correct name is Edwin Owenâ€”his mother's brother, whose name was George, lived and died a lunaticâ€”he lived for many years with the prisoner's motherâ€”the father of the prisoner's mother "had a married sister who had been in an Asylum, and who never regained her facultiesâ€”my daughter is at present in a private asylum, this is the name of it on this receipt for last quarter's chargesâ€”I have two other daughters who are now in a precarious position as to their mental healthâ€”I do not know what the result will be to them when they hear this horrible taleâ€”I have sent one out of town to get out of the way this weekâ€”I knew the prisoner's father, he died a confirmed dipsomanicâ€”he squandered in drink the fortunes of his wife, his own two sisters, and his mother.
Cross-examined. My wife's name was Eliza Sarah Freemanâ€”her father's name was Henry Freeman, and the prisoner's mother's name

was Helen Freemanâ€”I knew my wife's fatherâ€”he was of perfect mind all through his lifeâ€”he had three sons and three daughtersâ€”the third daughter's name was Carolineâ€”she was the lunaticâ€”she left the Asylum some years before her death and resided at home with her children.

JAMES SCOTT . I am medical officer for Brixton Prisonâ€”the prisoner has been detained there since December 24thâ€”he was put under close observa
tion on January 1stâ€”I have specially directed my attention to the state of his mindâ€”I have seen nothing to indicate insanity.

Cross-examined. I had some written statements as to the prisoner's family history, but I had no means of testing themâ€”I have examined the prisoner, the shape of his head is somewhat peculiar, one part is more prominent, with a slight depression on each sideâ€”he says he had a fall about fifteen years agoâ€”there might be some thickening of the bone, which might cause local painâ€”it would not necessarily affect his brainâ€”it might lead to some affection of the brain but not necessarily to atrophyâ€”cases where wholesale murders are committed are unusualâ€”there might be strong original taint where insanity runs in collateral branches of a familyâ€”indifference to human life is frequently shown in cases of homicidal maniaâ€”insane men often use the same methods and have the same motives as sane menâ€”they show a good deal of cunning and ability in concocting their schemesâ€”people who become insane often have colossal schemes, the mind in a way is always at work; schemes which would be impossible to a sane manâ€”a person might be suffering from homicidal mania and not show any outward signs that he is likely to commit a terrible crime-homicidal impulses would not last over any length of timeâ€”it is possible, but not usual for homicidal mania to return with uncontrollable impulseâ€”cases of so called homicidal impulses are not numerousâ€”no murderer is normal, and it is very seldom that the motive for the murder is adequateâ€”a murderer is a departure from absolute soundness, although not legally insaneâ€”I should not necessarily describe him as mentally weakâ€”my opinion is that in this case there are things which a man who was in possession of his faculties might do.
Re-examined. If there had been any thickening of the bone of the skull affecting the brain I should have expected to find symptoms of itâ€”I found no symptoms of insanity in this case.
By the COURT. I have had considerable experience of observing people, some of whom have turned out insane and some saneâ€”I have had over twenty years of prison service.
GUILTY .
The Prisoner. "Now get on with it as quick as you like."
DEATH .
